column1: HUGE potential here. I think a few things need reworked.
1. Balance: jmzero's review goes in depth.
2. No discard pile: this i feel is an odd design choice
column2: since there's no discard pile
column3: all cards used immediately go back to the deck
column4: so attaining any new card is a constant lower percentile of getting any card in your deck on every turn. So you may never see your new card in play...ever. Since the deck is *shuffled* every turn. This is poor design
column5: you cant structure synergy here
column6: as you are constantly threatened to draw the same cards over and over. This just feeds into the balance problem
column7: of ""just grab the most OP cards and scrap the rest""

column2: nailed most of it. I will add shields (especially after unlocking a particular ship) are VERY exploitable. You can turtle up
column3: create drones forever
column4: and heal any dmg that gets by.

column1: 4. All events: now jmzero went over the crates. however
column2: many ? events are lackluster. you find a trader...repair your ship...get fuel...sell fuel...etc. the only promising one is the temple ruins
column3: but even that is just a choice of getting more credits at expense of fuel and hp
column4: 5 times. Also to add to the crate
column5: it doesn't help that the literal ""do-nothing"" iteration of that event can soft-lock the game!! (had it happen twice where the pop up doesn't go away ever
column6: the event never ends
column7: and i have to alt F4

column2: event
column3: etc. is just slow to show up or finish.

column1: even with these issues i can recommend this considering the alpha state. Potential buyers
column2: i would say if you like FTL and slay the spire and want to support the devs
column3: go for it
column4: otherwise
column5: wishlist it and wait.";9.3;1.0;36.0;292.0;Posted: 27 July

column1: It's less a deck-builder and more a card pool-builder - you have discard & draw mechanics
column2: but cards don't play in any sort of deck order. You can draw the same card in every hand

column1: The ability to explore sectors is cool
column2: but it's not very useful and can encourage you to time-waste. Having played this I can understand why FTL has an enemy fleet chasing you. It's quite possible to become self-sufficient (gaining fuel with every battle & self-repairing) and clean out an entire sector

column1: I enjoyed this game quite a bit
column2: enough to play for 30 hours
column3: but I really wish there was more meta progression (and more content!) Ships and difficulty modes are the only unlocks
column4: and I feel it would be much more engaging/addictive if there was something more to unlock
column5: such as different cards or bonuses. The atmosphere is good
column6: and I enjoyed the music and art style for what it is. I did think the giant ""FTW!"" after every battle was kind of childish and annoying
column7: but I got used to it eventually. I'd like to see some different enemies
column8: as on some maps I felt like I was just fighting the same three enemies on every battle (yawn.) The RNG didn't bother me as much as some other people
column9: I felt it added a layer of strategy and use for the hand-manipulating cards. I also liked that you could save mid-run. All in all
column10: if you enjoy roguelike deckbuilders and a space setting

column2: I normally don't do reviews on Steam
column3: however this game has made me make an exception. The easiest way for me to describe this game at the time of writing is FTL: Faster Than Light mixed with Slay the Spire with a slight influence from tactical rpg's. That being said
column4: there are a few issues at the moment I have noticed
column5: however it could just be my PC at the moment. First issue is in the intro cut-scene the audio jacks up near the end and transfers into the map. Second issue I found is the random encounter that shows all PoI (Places of Interest) on the map
column6: causing a soft lock
column7: however going to main menu then pressing continue resets the tile and allows you to continue playing. Third issue I found is when you run out of fuel
column8: you click the arrow
column9: the distress beacon dialogue appears in which you lose some credits and gain five fuel.

column1: The combat is good. I like the shield system where you can rollover shields to next turn
column2: unless you have the Kinetic Shield card or something else along those lines
column3: however I will say the GUI during combat is not my friend. The GUI is beautiful
column4: however there are no tool-tips except for equipment. If I ignite the enemy
column5: I have to remember how much ignite is on the enemy
column6: how much damage it might do
column7: etc. I see the icon under the enemy
column8: I just don't have any information to work with regarding that aspect.

column1: Synergies is an interesting concept. I like them to be honest
column2: and with the estimated 80 cards you're more likely to encounter synergy cards. It makes the actual deck-building fun
column3: and you can get some pretty interesting combinations. If you find an Ignite synergy with Nova Strike it's beautiful.

column2: I haven't messed around with this all too much. I have noticed that removing cards from your deck is a much more difficult process than adding cards to the deck. There's a few random encounters that allow you to remove cards
column3: and it's a beautiful sight that makes a grown man cry with joy.

column2: I would pick this game up if you like FTL and/or Slay the Spire. There's a few things that could deal with a bit of polish or reworking
column3: but otherwise it's a good game.

column1: I love the art style and design of the game. I have beaten the game on hardcore and draft with every ship. The game in its current state is very minimalistic. Each run through you need to eliminate most of the starter cards. Mass Driver is essential for every single deck
column2: this card needs to have a chance to be permanently destroyed each time it is used. I can make perfect draw decks with Mass Driver. The game is very easy simply by getting a few heal cards and getting as many +to max shield cards. What the game lacks most is meaningful interactions with aliens. They need to hire some cartoonists or comic strip writers to make some satirical and fun interactions with aliens. The game is too easy
column3: I can gauranteed win every single run through by farming a zone. This game needs to take a note from Slay the Spire and Hades by adding some scaling difficulty modifiers to keep players challenged and interested. I do recommend this game
column4: but many updates need to come.";120.3;1.0;3.0;130.0;Posted: February 26

column2: nice tunes... The only truly negative thing I can say about the game is its overreliance on RNG. I get it's meant to be a ""roguelike"" but the balance or lack thereof is all over the place. I can't begin to tell you the number of runs ended in the first sector because of several clusters of enemies that all spam their attacks and leave you at half or less health past the first encounter; then the sector one enemies that enjoy their 10 ~ 23 damage attacks.
enemy attack values vary wildly unlike yours which are static. Their 'Burn damage' also pierces/ignores your Shields/Block while yours can't do the same.
it's still entertaining for what it is but if the talk about its balancing or lack of certain elements common to deckbuilders of this kind puts you off
column3: I'd suggest waiting for a sale or watching someone else play it before deciding.";9.8;1.0;0.0;701.0;Posted: April 12

column1: I originally bought this game on itch.io in December
column2: back when it was in alpha 0.2.3
column3: so I have a lot more hours in the game than what is reflected on Steam. It's been really cool to see how much work the devs have put into it in just a few short months.

column2: FTW is a roguelike where you move a spaceship through several sectors of a galaxy toward a goal
column3: sort of like FTL
column4: but the combat uses cards (which are shaped like 3.5 inch floppies and are cute as hell) with different skills and effects
column5: similar to Slay the Spire. Because the loot and maps are randomized
column6: each game is unique and there are many different play styles you can go for in your deck. So
column7: I think it has a good amount of replay value
column8: even in this early alpha stage of development.

column1: I love the pixel art. I love the music and hope they add more. I love the little references (""twisted firestarter"") and the quirkiness of some of the enemies. It's a fun game and I appreciate the insane amount of work they've put into it in just the three or so months since I bought it.
At this point (alpha 0.5.0) my biggest complaint is money. It's too easy to acquire and that makes it too easy to buy a lot of overpowered equipment at shops. I think either money should be more rare
column2: or that loot should get progressively more expensive. That
column3: I think
column4: would help balance the game and make it more difficult. It's a roguelike
column5: after all. It's supposed to be hard! Aside from that
column6: I think they've got a good thing going here and I look forward to seeing what else they do with it in future builds.";16.1;1.0;0.0;154.0;Posted: March 29

Summit Reviews
column3: to see more high-quality reviews regularly.

column1: Indie made. Space-faring roguelike. Futuristic sci-fi setting. Procedurally generated 2.5D star map. Turn-based strategic exploration. 2D side-on
column2: turn-based card battler. Ship vs ship tactical combat. Session only deck-building. Requires constant deck management. RNG can cause heavy imbalance. Imbalance makes it very challenging. Quality pixel graphics & art. Matched by synth-pop soundtrack. Short on content. Some variety of components. Made to be replayable. Singleplayer only

column1: For the Warp provided a mixed experience which has some surprisingly involved card-driven space combat. However
column2: the hefty use of RNG gives it an unbalanced nature. One that is further complicated by a lack of mechanisms to limit its impact. Some gamers may find its content on the low side
column3: but it has been made to be replayed. Very likely the reason for its steep difficulty curve.

column1: For the Warp is a well made but unbalanced game. Strategic gameplay is good but could do with a few more additions and added variation. Tactical combat is at times an enjoyable experience with several viable strategies and synergies available. However
column2: the substance deck-building possesses is affected by a level of RNG that causes its overall difficulty to rise steeply
column3: detrimentally impacting balance.

column1: This results in a frustrating experience which is why its rating falls from being worthwhile to a purchase
column2: though only just.";17.5;1.0;21.0;923.0;Posted: 10 April

column1: FOR THE WARP definitely a game i will be playing for a long time. Its a deck builder where you start out with a bunch of cards which during the course of your journey you can trade or sell for resources such as fuel
column2: new weapons and ship upgrades etc. Card selection is vast and it all makes sense with the science fiction theme and how they play out. Combat is fun where you can win if you play your cards right :) even when it seems the odds against you. Keeping your shields fully charged is very important to prevent physical ship damage. You will meet others in your travels who can provide repairs for something in return or give you fuel when your running low. I think one time someone even did this for free.

column1: When defeating a boss you will unlock a new ship with new gear adding the variety of things that can be done. Maps are areas of space you can cross any way you want while trying to avoid too many hostile encounters as you attempt to get to the warp exit location. The maps are full of random encounters such as distress calls and ruined civilizations where something foreboding happened in the past. You will also come across merchant zones where you can purchase new cards.
Music is good though at the moment i believe there are only like two or three songs. One for exploration and another for combat. Since its early access many are hoping more music will be added.

column2: BUY IT! PLAY IT! Embark on a epic space age journey across the galaxy where futuristic riches await with all their glory and terror!";1.6;1.0;4.0;1469.0;Posted: August 20

column1: This one is tough for me and may come across as a negative review
column2: but it really isn't. I absolutely adore the overall idea of this game. A spaceship version of Slay the Spire? Hell yes! However
column3: it often feels like it's deliberately holding the player back from having too much fun.

column1: The game ends a zone or two too soon
column2: right when your build is the most fun to play. The Hardcore mode levels up as you play Normal and Draft
column3: but there's no way to level it back down again. It's stuck at Level 10 for me which makes the first zone nearly impossible out the gate. Speaking of Draft mode
column4: it's my favorite
column5: but some ships are just plain better for it than others
column6: which is sad. I wish each ship had more tangible differences than just the amount of hull/shields it starts with. It's also difficult to build an efficient deck without predictable scrapping opportunities. The shop card offerings are very limited and there's no way to sell back excess equipment. I'm often swimming in credits and loaded down in stuff I don't want but can't get rid off. Definitely detracts from the overall fun of the experience.

column1: Is it worth the price? Sure
column2: but I was really hoping for more longevity from it. I'm giving it a recommend because I've had a good deal of fun with it
column3: but there is a lot of room for improvement. Also
column4: the game would be PERFECT for Steam Workshop. I can already imagine the awesome mods the community could create.";36.0;1.0;1.0;332.0;Posted: May 13

column1: This game is an absolute gem and well worth picking up if you enjoy deck-building and space-themed strategy.
If you enjoy Slay The Spire or similar deck-building games and you have played space-themed titles like Eve Online and Elite Dangerous... oh boy

column1: It's a super well polished approach to the genre
column2: featuring beautiful pixel art
column3: a catchy soundtrack and great game design. The hints of lore in this Alpha version already have me intrigued about all the ""races"" and very distinguishable ship designs
column4: the ""oomph"" of card synergy power is very well executed
column5: the feeling of challenge and the achievement when you beat each of the bosses is on point and it even had me gasping at certain random encounters (that I won't spoil) I did not expect
column6: but have left me further intrigued.

column1: I have only managed to collect a single ""legendary"" grade card so far but it already had me working to build a deck around it and I could not put the game down until I managed to unlock all the ships available so far and take them for a spin.

column2: I am very eager to continue playing and for all the ways I can see this game growing towards its 1.0 release. I can estimate that the content in this current build will probably have me playing it for around 10 hours
column3: but I will definitely follow its development for the chance to play more For The Warp.

For The Warp is a good game in the making. I've put a decent amount of time into it at the time of this review (about 15 hours or so) and I feel like I've seen pretty much everything the game can throw at me by now. There are definitely some cool combos (I personally enjoy the 0 cost discard cards with the 'draw cards and gain energy when you discard' equipment) and fun gameplay but there are definitely some balance issues.

column2: you quickly realize that some strategies are just better than others because the cards needed for those strategies are the best cards. When I get a bad first shop and don't find many useful early cards in the first area
column3: I end up just starting over because my deck doesn't have the defensive capabilities to survive multiple fights in the second phase. If you need specific cards to progress past the early stages of the game (I'm looking at you barrel roll/cloaking device) then what's the point of adopting any other early strategy that doesn't best support these cards?

column1: An example of a game that I think has perfected the 'balance' concept is Slay the Spire. Any strategy can win the game if you are smart about how you play it and get the key cards/relics you need for that strategy. This game can get there
column2: but it definitely needs work. I will say though that it's a good time while you figure it out
column3: but once you've figured out what works and what doesn't it feels a bit stale.

column1: I still think it's worth picking up though as long as the developers are actively making good changes to the game. Being a part of the evolution of a good game is pretty exciting and if you're okay with hitting a few snags here and there
column2: go for it. Just remember that it's still a work in progress.";38.8;1.0;0.0;45.0;Posted: April 1

This game has a lot of potential. I like its style and base mechanics. But it's hard to really see the good parts in this game right now because of some fairly dire problems:
1. Balance. There doesn't seem to be any kind of ""base rate"" these cards are built on. Like
column2: there's a card that increases shield capacity by 1 for 1 energy. Another card charges shields by 10 for 1 energy. Another card makes a 4/2 drone for 2 energy. There's also a card called ""AI Supremacy"" that gives you 10 shield capacity
column3: 10 shield charges
column4: and 4 4/4 drones. Going by the established rates
column5: this card should cost at least 19 (ignoring the fact that it also gives you all these effects in one card). Instead it costs 3. Yes it's ""mythic""... but that should mean it's maybe twice as good
column6: not 6 or 10 times as good. Having cards this strong makes your strategy and the enemy's strategy irrelevant - you just play your card and win. Things won't be perfectly balanced... but I feel like there could be a better attempt here.

column1: 2. Easy Exploits. Like Slay the Spire
column2: it feels like health is a resource that should slowly exhaust through a stage
column3: and most game mechanics here seem to suggest this was the plan. But there's a card that heals you and doesn't ""deactivate"". This means it's easy to kill all but one enemy
column4: shield up
column5: and loop through your deck until you're healed to full. I think there's one for credits too. You shouldn't be able to get these kinds of effects so easily (ie. with a single card and some patience). Learn the lessons of the other games in this space. These cards should exhaust.

column1: 3. Do-nothing events. Whatever is in the mysterious crate
column2: don't have it be nothing. Again
column3: I get this is early access... but I've played the game twice
column4: and it feels like I've opened 6 empty crates. Events don't need fancy graphics or something - just placeholder in _something_.

column2: if I was you
column3: dear reader
column4: and if I was looking for a game to play now - I'd add this game to my wishlist
column5: and come back to it once it has had a little more time to bake. But you shouldn't forget it
column6: because I think it could be good.";4.6;1.0;252.0;493.0;Posted: 28 March

Design flaws like that are indicative that a developer is either clueless and has never worked in any real professional capacity or that they just don't care.";7.7;0.0;3.0;87.0;Posted: April 2

column2: the theme and general direction this game is taking. Pixel art spaceships and roguelike.....take my credits! But For the Warp (FtW) makes you appreciate FTL
column3: Slay the spire (StS) and many other roguelikes;

column1: I am not enjoying the gameplay right now. It feels very RNG heavy and I'm constantly getting my butt kicked. The first ship is not very good with it's measly shield cap of 10hp and you will routinely run into groups of 3 enemies who hit for 9dmg each a round. Bosses hit for 10-20
column2: and mid sized enemies can also do 10-20 damage. It's very hard to keep your shields up while also putting up an offense. The second ship is immediately better boasting 15shield cap and a ton of attack and draw cards. The game drastically gets more fun in the second ship
column3: but the world is still wonky and not set up in an approachable way. I hope the other ships are cooler still but I don't feel inspired to play more and unlock them.

column1: The grid you fly around on is frustrating. I find I""m getting bombarded with enemies
column2: then bombarded with allied ships but there isn't any way for me to know ahead of time what I will run into. In FTL you could see the whole region and make a guess at which routes to avoid and which ones would be better. In FtW you only know one space ahead and backtracking costs precious fuel. You will run out resources.

column1: In SlayTheSpire you could also plan ahead how many bosses/rests/merchants you'd roughly encounter. In FtW you can't plan at all. I""m often sitting outside the boss gate with 10%hp and not enough fuel to explore for help. Was I supposed to power through in a straight line? How many encounters should I risk for loot? It's incomprehensible.
I miss that in FTL the stations all offered the same services. You could always buy fuel
column2: repair and purchase from a wide variety of weapons
column3: drones and ship upgrades. SlayTheSpire had a similarly good merchant who offered card removal and card upgrades along with his RNG items. FtW could really benefit from stable merchants. The cost of fuel and repair is wildly different and making that last fuel jump to a station that doesn't sell fuel is very frustrating. I could see space games drop fuel as a mechanic if I""m honest.

column1: The merchants in FtW would be better if they had actual selection. Three cards and one equipment is silly small. There are many deck styles you could build in this game. Either make the cards cheaper so that you can buy a large number and design your play deck and side deck
column2: or give the players way more selection. In one instance I had a significant amount of money
column3: and I bought more equipment than I could use
column4: but there is nothing you can do with it afterwards. No merchant buys equipment from you and it's not relevant to any story based encounters. So if you don't plan on using the cards
column5: you can't reliably get rid of them and they don't serve a story purpose....can I send the out the airlock?

column1: Ultimately I want this game to be good but I don't like it right now. I am leaving a down vote so that the Devs see this feedback
column2: but I also hope that other players will play the game in hopes that the devs get the resources they need to continue. I won't be refunding and will keep my fingers crossed that some of my concerns are addressed
column3: or that other improvements are made.";2.1;0.0;19.0;220.0;Posted: 29 March

column2: bug in the middle of the game because of that...

column1: I've played a lot of FTL and Slay the Spire as well as many other deckbuilding/exploration/roguelikes. They are my favorite games
column2: and so I was sad that this one missed the mark for me. It looked right up my alley
column3: but the problem was that there was just too much RNG in the way without a lot of time to counter it. I couldn't find the mechanic to scrap cards fast enough so my deck became bloated fast
column4: and I kept running into unavoidable unwinnable fights. I investigated one space and fought some mega-ship that did 30-50 damage a shot. I had the card to escape a combat but I was dead before I drew it.

column1: And why is my starting hand only 3 cards? When there are three ships each swinging for 9 damage on the first round and I draw 3 base attacks it's not much help. Also
column2: 3-9 is not an acceptable range of damage for me to plan around
column3: nor is 10-18. That's too much control for the RNG to have and I'm not interested in continuing to play until the RNG gods deem it appropriate for me to win.

column1: I do like that your shields carry over if you don't use them
column2: but that just means I over-shield every time and only attack when I'm above the max shield. shrink the ranges
column3: or maybe do away with them altogether
column4: but at least shrink them.

column1: I'm more than willing to keep trying and to figure it out
column2: but then there is the issue that the core mechanics were not very fun. I don't see why I need to select my ship in order to shield if I'm the only ship that's there that logically I would want to shield. Explain to me why I have to select a ship to attack if there is only one target. It would be more fun if there was a right-click default action for cards that are obvious on how a general player would use them.
the cutscenes and dialog aren't fast enough for me. Put the text up there
column3: allow me to hit enter to skip it. Every single time you approach something t h e g a m e h a s t o m a k e y o u w a i t t o r e a d t h e d e s c r i p t i o n and it bores me every time. I read fast and I don't play games to be bored. Maybe there's a setting to control this in the options
column4: fine
column5: but whatever the fastest setting in should be the default and there should be a setting to slow it down if you like long-drawn out time to read text because I'm going to go ahead and assume that's the minority.

column1: It's very possible this game could hook people but for me there are too many games out there without these issues

snappier

For The Warp has a lot of charm.

column2: the music is fun and appropriate.

column1: But the game is severely lacking in the balance department.
This lack of balance really makes you relinquish any feeling of real freedom that your choices matter; as you can make every ""perfect"" play and you'll still lose pretty quickly.
The difficulty stacked up against you cannot be overstated
column2: and the constant over-powered opponents are a wall too high to climb with skill
column3: as you'll often feel like the encounters you win are due to pure luck.

column1: Attacks have no ""chance"" to hit either-- just a range of damage it WILL do.
You can never actively evade or dodge. You can never attempt to escape an opponent who is too overwhelming for you.
So you're stuck just watching your whole run get blown away due to a random (and seemingly likely chance) you'll see an opponent who just mops the floor with you.

column2: you start the game with 100 coins and can buy from a selection of 3-4 random cards.

column1: You are stuck using your incredibly under-powered deck of actions against opponents which can out-damage you
column2: out-shield you
column3: and have the benefit of numbers on you almost every combat.

column1: You most certainly will run out of fuel EVERY game
column2: as the only way to stay alive
column3: being so severely outgunned all the time
column4: is to try and avoid conflict (and you can't).

column1: You don't make enough money to do anything important
column2: nor will you run across a way to fix your ship's shields.

column1: Running out of fuel will invite even more overpowered encounters to spawn directly on you-- to where you will eventually throw your hands up and put the game back on the shelf.

I can't recommend this game in its current state. It's too unbalanced and you won't want to play very long when you feel like the game constantly ♥♥♥♥♥ you without any determinable merit to the challenge.";0.9;0.0;4.0;353.0;Posted: March 21

I don't think I can recommend For the Warp in its current state (January 2021). After three hours
column2: I already beat the game once after 4-5 tries and I don't have that urge to try and beat the game with the other ships like I do in other roguelites.

column1: Encounters are fairly repetitive with low variance and there doesn't seem to be much variety in enemy types. All enemies seem to do mostly the same thing just with varying HP pools. It's not even close to Slay the Spire where different encounters require you to approach the enemies differently.
Card balance seems a little off. A number of cards seem to require you to get other cards to make them useful
column2: but there's no guarantee you're ever even going to see cards of those types. On the other hand
column3: I have been able to make some broken combos using cards that aren't crap on their own.

column1: There's also poor explanation of mechanics. For example
column2: one card I've seen has the Explosive property. It sounds like it's supposed to ignore X% of armor
column3: but it just says 0% on there. Is there something I'm missing? I also still don't understand how the Synergy keyword works with its vague description. Another card tells me it does more damage for each ""Plasma"" type in my hand
column4: but I don't know how to tell if a card is Plasma type or not. I thought maybe it was if the card had ""Plasma"" in the name
column5: but my starter cards with Plasma in the name didn't seem to count.

column2: the game looks and sounds pretty good
column3: although I do wish cards had more on-screen effects. The game also has a twist on deck building where there is no discard
column4: which I find interesting. Cards you play in a turn immediately get sent back and shuffled into the deck. This causes you to approach deck building a little different than the typical deck building approach where you don't reshuffle until you've played your entire deck.

column2: I think they need to work on card balance and make encounters actually interesting. With every encounter playing out the same
column3: the game gets boring extremely fast.";2.9;0.0;8.0;2352.0;Posted: January 21

column1: There are some interesting concepts here but some weird decisions that
column2: ultimately
column3: I didn't enjoy.

column1: * It's bizarre to me that you start with 3 cards instead of a full deck... No idea why that decision was made (but I'm assuming there is one...?) This means you'll easily take 9-27 damage (probably more later on) without being able to charge your shields or prevent damage (unless you get lucky with your draw on those first three cards) That's my biggest complaint
column2: really. I flew through the first system no problem but died within two encounters on the second system due to this mechanic.

column1: * I enjoyed the sci-fi spaceship/deckbuilding setting and the art is pretty good. Seeing the animations for the corresponding card you played is pretty cool. The backgrounds are bright and colorful and it's always fun to look at. The music was pretty great but seemed to be a bit repetitive?

* 'Burn' (think 'bleed' in other games - damage over time) doesn't take effect until the end of the enemy turn... which is a strange decision as well in my opinion. It doesn't allow the damage to be a real 'game-changer'. You'll take the enemy's attacks and THEN they die... which really hurts your momentum on a run since your HP carries over.

column2: I only played this for about 0.4 hours before dying and deciding I didn't enjoy it. It's possible that the game continues to open up as you progress (as deck-building games usually do) I want to like this game and will definitely keep an eye on it as it continues to progress through early access. If you like this genre of game you might really vibe with it... I'm sure I'll pick it up again in the future but I don't think it's something I want to play just yet.";0.4;0.0;0.0;509.0;Posted: September 14

column2: this game has a lot of great features and has some compelling gameplay. However
column3: there are three things that kill it for me because they lead too far down the path of heavy RNG.

column1: 1) The shuffler makes no sense. The fact that you don't discard cards and that every time you draw a hand that you are pulling from your entire deck is against the foundation of what a deck builder game is supposed to be. It has all of the other facets of how to build and manipulate your deck but the player should be drawing from a shuffled stack and continue to do such until the discard pile needs to be shuffled back in. I might have been less opposed to this if you could freely discard cards from your deck without needing to pay for it or have NPC's want to buy them during events. But as it stands
column2: it is far to easy to get a 18-20 card deck and that is far too much RNG when doing pool draws.

column1: 2) Draft mode is not worth playing due to the design of ships and certain cards. Each ship has a core deck archetype that goes with them. To top it off
column2: you are shown 10 cards to pick from
column3: then 9
column4: then 8
column5: etc. While this would certainly be what you would experience playing Magic: the Gathering
column6: the cards do not have enough synergy to interface with each other in this format let alone to build a half way viable starter deck that matches the ship you selected. Also
column7: you select the ship BEFORE you draft which should be the other way around. See what comes to you and what archetype you can build towards then decide what ship you want. The problem stated in #1 compounds this since you might not have that many shield cards and drawing them when you are getting blasted for 40 damage a round in the first map is not a good experience.

column2: there are certain cards you need to make your ship's archetype deck come together and there is no way to guarantee that you get those. As such
column3: it leads to runs that are destined to fail because you
column4: through RNG
column5: just don't power up your deck to the point that you can handle later encounters. Especially when you get screwed by not drawing what you need from your pool (see #1) for several turns.

column1: I like the premise of the game and it has a great foundation. Hopefully
column2: these issues will get addressed by the developer in the near future as I look forward to playing this game after those patches land.";12.2;0.0;16.0;235.0;Posted: 10 January

column1: It really doesn't stand out at all. It's just another one of those deck builder games. It doesn't have much in the way of charm or originality.";0.7;0.0;1.0;950.0;Posted: May 12
The card design is extremely simple
column2: the diversity between 'ships' limited
column3: the difficulty is extremely low and
column4: perhaps worst of all
column5: it's so utterly slow.

column2: enemy health/shield pools
column3: and the limited damage output of even your most synergy-dependant
column4: powerful attacks
column5: battles take a very long time by ""roguelite deckbuilder"" standards (though perhaps you may be used to the pace if you've played a lot of Deck of Ashes). But a big issue is that each map - of the 5 you go through for one 'run' of the game - is filled to the brim with enemy encounters and there's very rarely anything stopping you from going through all of them
column6: plus the myriad of beneficial random encounters and 'quest'-like events dragging you back and forth over the map very
column7: very slowly.

column1: I suspect the ""Fuel"" mechanic - as well as your health limits - is intended to prevent you from just fighting constantly for huge quantities of money and other partial benefits
column2: but it fails to function because there are cards that let you easily earn Fuel in-battle
column3: as well as heal in-battle
column4: as well as even permanently remove selected cards from your deck in-battle. As a result
column5: you can easily just leave 1 enemy alive in a battle then spend all of the time you need healing to full
column6: optimizing your deck and restocking your fuel (until the enemy eventually runs away).

column2: a very poor handling of in-battle resources with out-of-battle
column3: run-long resources leaves a glacially paced
column4: unfulfilling and fundamentally boring game
column5: lacking inventive classes
column6: deckbuilding
column7: story or much of anything else. I do give some credence to the aesthetic and theming of the game
column8: but even that runs dry quickly when there appears to be as little as 3 (4?) visually distinct enemies per map
column9: and (not counting bosses) seemingly only about 18 or so types of enemies in the game.

column1: And those 18 enemy types are painfully similar. In fact
column2: same with bosses. Enemies just... attack you for X-Y damage
column3: shield themselves (basically self-heal) for X-Y damage
column4: and... that's actually almost it. Occasionally they will take an offensive action like decrease your max shield or place an absolutely trivial damage-over-time effect to you (like ""1 damage over 3 turns"" at a time when enemies are regularly doing 10-14 damage with regular attacks). Occasionally an enemy may spawn a new enemy which... just does the same thing. Deal X-Y damage
column5: shield themselves for X-Y
column6: or do some minor amount of DoT or max shield decrease.

column1: On top of all of the many issues
column2: even if they fixed the ability to exploit battles to maximize all of your resource gains too easily
column3: your cards are both super slow and yet they easily let you break the game. In my first battle
column4: I was just playing a ""barrel roll"" card every turn rendering me literally immune to damage on each turn
column5: and there seemed to be no penalty or limitation to doing so.

column2: minimal content
column3: minimal variety
column4: minimum difficulty
column5: terrible pacing. This is
column6: sadly
column7: probably the worst deckbuilding roguelike game I've played on Steam.";2.9;0.0;4.0;380.0;Posted: August 15

but I don't enjoy it as the way the game was intended to be enjoyed. Kill a giant creature? Great! Rewards! Do more! Feels like how most of the 10 or so friends playing this game enjoy it. column9: but these joys are far and in between long hours of play. I love open worlds but I also love characters in them. This world feels empty. I barely see any other people and when I do its completely possible I might miss them or kill them

I really took my time with this From Soft game. This is the first time I decided to do everything I needed to do for the Platinum in my first run through of one of their games. I kind of regret doing that
column2: because I did have to do a bit of research before continuing through the whole game
column3: but for the most part I played the game blind and what an incredible experience it was.

column1: I cannot get over the talent that this developer has for world design
column2: art style
column3: game mechanics
column4: and did I mention world design? My god. So good.

column1: Every time I would push forward into a new area
column2: whether it was Stormveil
column3: Caelid
column4: Weeping Peninsula
column5: Luirnia
column6: Altus Plateau
column7: Consecrated snowfields
column8: and on and on
column9: every single new push was something completely new
column10: fresh and exciting.

column1: I have seen some complaints online about the fact that they re-used assets and my jaw literally dropped open reading that.. Do they have recurring areas? Of course
column2: but pretty much every single rehash is side areas. Every. Single. major area and legacy dungeons are just completely unique and beautiful.

column1: By the time I got to Altus and saw how wildly different that area was - and by this point I was easily 100 hours into the game
column2: I was just in awe how the game kept surprising me and blowing my mind.

column1: I personally thought every major boss fight was a win except for the Elden Beast one. I just found it annoying and nonstop running around trying to get a single hit and then running around some more. Other than that though
column2: I had a blast.

column1: This game is now the second most played game in my Steam library by hours played only coming behind the Witcher 3 which is one of my favorite games of all time
column2: so that really says something. I am not someone who typically puts hundreds and hundreds (thousands) of hours into games. I like to beat the game
column3: get my enjoyment out of it and then move on to a new experience. So anytime I put upwards of 100 hours or more into a game
column4: you can rest assured it is a game that REALLY held my attention.

column2: this game is amazing i would totally recommend.";4.6;1.0;0.0;31.0;Posted: May 23

column1: Elden Ring is a truly beautiful and well-designed game. This is the first From Software game I have played since the original Dark Souls
column2: which at the time was one of my all-time favorite gaming experiences.

column1: The world is absolutely stunning: My first playthrough I was in awe of the landscapes you happen upon
column2: some of which you aren't even expecting. They were so great I ended up actually buying the looking glass just to be able to more fully experience the views (and take countless screenshots).

column1: The game really brings back some beautiful memories of some of my most beloved gaming experiences: Back when quests consisted of actually reading the items given to you and not just constantly following a quest marker. Having said that
column2: I must admit that if it wasn't for the online wiki
column3: there are a number of quests I would have never figured out how to continue. This is unfortunately in part to the open-world nature: Many quests are somewhat ""linear"" in that they continue from place to place along the path that the game may expect you to follow
column4: however since you can decide
column5: for the most part
column6: to skip around areas or follow towards main opponents without checking every curve and corner
column7: they are still very easy to overlook.

column2: voice acting
column3: and overall sound of the game are astounding. As someone who usually plays games for the gameplay and not the story
column4: I found myself actually listening to the characters. I suppose it helps that the ""dialogue"" was short during each encounter
column5: but it really added to the experience of the world
column6: and in some cases
column7: a true care for the characters.

column1: I don't remember much from Dark Souls and haven't been keeping track of the other games to compare crafting and upgrading functionalities (where present)
column2: but I generally liked the approach here. What I somewhat disliked was the inability to use ""sword grease"" on the special weapons. I guess it makes sense
column3: but I would have loved for it to still be possible
column4: even if then tremendously nerfed
column5: if nothing else then for the asthetic. :)

column1: Despite my love for the game (not including multiplayer
column2: which I am now starting on after getting all achievements)
column3: there are two very big annoyances:

column1: 1. Despite my fast computer and great graphics card
column2: the game still crashes on a regular basis. When it doesn't crash completely
column3: there are still significant stutters
column4: that just so happen want to occur in the middle of boss fights or during plattforming
column5: leaving me almost guaranteed to die.

column1: 2. Lack of ultrawide support: Part of the reason I didn't play multiplayer was because of the ultrawide fix requiring disabling anti-cheat and playing exclusively offline. This made the game absolutely beautiful and a treat to play
column2: but it blows my mind how little effort From Software seems to put in their PC ports: That was the reason I haven't played anything since Dark Souls after switching to PC gaming
column3: and it's depressing to see that it's still the case
column4: despite the fact that the ultrawide fix (even if offline only) was made available practically instantly after the games release.

column1: Aside from those major issues though
column2: the game is tremendous and a lot of fun to play. It is so much fun to try new play styles and explore the game in a whole new way by searching for different talismans or focusing on incantations or sorceries over weapons
just put Dark Souls 3 in an open world with some extra stuff and call it a day.

column1: Elden Ring is a game where I am not exactly sure where I should put it when it comes to a rating of 1-10.
Regardless of what I think about it
column2: I still enjoyed it and had a great time playing through it for the first time
column3: but alas
column4: my desire to replay it is non-existent. Once I got my final achievement to 100% it
column5: I dropped it.

column2: and it's downsides
column3: just like any other game ever made
column4: and in this review
column5: I will attempt to share my views and thoughts on it.

column1: -There's a big world out there to explore
column2: and as it's open-world
column3: you have the freedom to explore on your own pace and go wherever you want. You can make it hard for yourself by rushing to the first boss you see and trying to fight it while likely under-leveled and under-geared
column4: or you can stop to explore the world and come back to the boss once you've gotten some gear upgrades and level ups.

column1: This allows each playthrough to be just a little big different depending on the paths you choose.
-Exploration is rewarded. There is a lot of different kinds of dungeons scattered around the world. They remind me a lot of dungeoneering from Runescape. You enter a dungeon
column2: fight some monsters
column3: solve some puzzles
column4: fight a boss at the end and get loot. It's always interesting to find one and wonder what kind of loot you'll find.

column1: There's also these smaller little dungeons that hold a chest inside but with no enemies
column2: but these require you to have a key item which you can find while you explore the world or purchase from merchants.
but it is a welcome addition regardless.
allowing for lots of build variety. There's your basic weaponry which are still powerful and can be infused with the ashes of war to provide different weapon arts
column3: and then there's your unique weaponry
column4: powerful and equipped with their own unique weapon art.

column2: other than for the ashes for war which I found to be a decent addition
column3: but it is a plus regardless.

column2: the spirit summons are a cool
column3: although somewhat controversial addition. Torrent
column4: your steed
column5: is there to make traversing the world less slow and painful
column6: and there's even a crafting system that allows you to put some resources you gather to use.

column1: You have new spells like the madness inflicting ones
column2: and new ailments like the blackflame which saps away your opponents health for a short period of time.

column1: The satisfaction of beating a boss is still there
column2: so if that's all you need from this game
column3: go ahead and buy it.

column1: -The world feels empty in some areas. For example
column2: the lake by the academy is so barren that it's just a W key simulator. There's a reason you get fast traveling right from the get-go
column3: otherwise it would be torturous.

column1: Not to mention that often you wont even be able to fast travel since some random enemy you didn't even know existed within a kilometer radius somehow is in combat with you.
-Mostly pointless crafting system. In my over 100 hours put in the game
column2: I never used the crafting system more than once
column3: and I was only testing it out. It feels like an after thought to me
column4: giving the player the ability to craft some basic consumable equipment out of scrap they'll find littering the game-world.

column1: I read somewhere that there's about 120 bosses in the game. Now ask yourself and don't lie: How many of those do you think are unique rather than repeated bosses
column2: different bosses mashed up together
column3: gank bosses
column4: or normal enemies made into bosses?

column1: Not to mention the fact that the unique bosses seem to be designed around you using spirit summons
column2: and purposefully delay their attacks so that learning their move-sets and timing is mandatory.

column1: -Armor is still useless. It's just like Dark Souls 3
column2: armor is there only for the looks
column3: and barely makes a difference at all. Poise is still a broken mess
column4: and the defenses and resistances just don't matter.

column1: Your better off going naked into battle so you wont be getting heavy load.
-The traditional Dark Souls quest-design does not work well for this game.

column2: you would likely come across the npc's naturally as you progressed since it was a more linear game
column3: but since Elden Ring is an open-world game
column4: the chances of you coming across that npc that you just talked to in the game world are very slim. Using Google is almost mandatory for this game if you want to do all the optional questlines.

column1: I never played PvP so that's why I didn't mention it in my review.
I'd still recommend the game if you're an old fan of From
column2: but if you're only just looking to get into the souls-franchise
column3: I wouldn't recommend starting with this.

column1: Dark Souls and Bloodborne are still my favorites in the From Software catalog.";109.3;1.0;0.0;107.0;Posted: May 22

column1: Just to clarify this review may come off as negative because I only want to complain about the things that annoyed me or that I disliked. However in spite of that this game is definitely worth playing and has around 150 hours of content or more. This game is one of the only games where I actually want to look in every corner of the world
column2: read every item description and discover the secrets behind the world. Discovery is one of the funnest parts about Elden Ring where every boss gives you a unique item and some of the areas you see are really interesting and beautiful.

column1: Some combat additions they added that I liked a lot were the new crouch and jump attack
column2: bringing back power stance weapons (although its automatic) and the ability to fight and travel on a horse.

column1: Firstly I'd like to address a hopefully non-issue in the future
column2: Computer Performance Issues.

column1: Currently in the game I am still getting the occasional lag spike and choppy frames
column2: this is not nearly as bad as how the game was first released however these issues still make boss fights incredibly annoying and frustrating at times since every second counts. I'm using an alienware m15 for reference so pretty decent specs.

column1: The swamps were really diverse with different colours
column2: styles and Caelid was really cool however they were all mostly empty and had little reason to explore. Swamp of Aeonia you can just cheat your way though on a horse. Lake of rot looks amazing
column3: however its completely devoid of content
column4: there's no reason to stay there other than beating a repeat boss.

column1: When killing a main boss instead of just fading away instead there should be a final critical hit. Almost every boss already has an inbuilt stagger/parry stun
column2: it would be much better and realistic if we finished the boss with a critical hit.

column1: There are few colossal sword options and they are just not really that viable.
You should be able to duplicate any remembrance at any walking mausoleum. There should also be another reason to knock down these walking castles.
There should be more caves and special areas
column2: these areas should also be more diverse. Limgrave perfectly encapsulates this but as you continue through the game its like they forgot to add more content and make it unique. Its like they went from Limgrave to Raya Lucaria then to Caelid and so on until areas like consecrated snowfield which are gigantic empty plains in a sense. The fire giant mountain top is probably the worst case of this in the entire game. However this is only in terms of special areas to explore with unique items
column3: pretty much every area is really well designed with beautiful sights and great use of elevation
column4: it just needs to be filled better with more diverse enemies
column5: etc.

column1: There are incomplete npc questlines and cut npc quest content which are crucial for lore world building and hinting important areas of the map.

column2: well designed and unique
column3: you want to interact with them however the game tries to make this as difficult as possible. It is basically impossible to finish npc questlines without a guide because npcs just randomly appear in different places without any hit or indication. Also npcs are still the same as other dark soul games they just stand in a specific spot and never move unless if they are hostile. Interacting with specific npcs will allow you to summon them to specific boss fights which is a really great feature however this should extend to them travelling the world with you.

column2: now lets address the ♥♥♥♥ show which is Fia the Deathbed Companion
column3: the Loathsome Dungeater and the Ever brilliant Goldmask. They are first introduced in the massive epic introduction at the start of the game and for each one you as the player interact with them and help them achieve their goals
column4: which is tied to the Elden Ring and consequently the end of the game. Fia
column5: Dungeater and Goldmask are great characters with great designs and dialogue however the only good/complete questline is Fias which feels fitting for the magnitude of her character. I will give a very high level summary just to show why her questline is fitting for her being an endgame npc. Essentially to complete her questline
column6: you search for clues of death
column7: go to the deepest part of the world
column8: fight and defeat an ancient dark dragon and mend the rune of the deathbed prince. Meanwhile Dungeater's quest is just release him
column9: to then kill him
column10: feed him and hear him howl which is incredibly disturbing however unfitting of such a defiled
column11: disgusting and infamous character. If Dungeaters quest is garbage I don't even know what to say about Goldmasks
column12: the only notable thing about Goldmasks quest other than running across the entire continent is discovering a mystery which you solve using another npc (turtle pope). It shouldn't be more enjoyable reading people on reddit discuss their character then actually experience their questlines. And when you think it couldn't get any worse just watch the endings for each of them
column13: complete disappointment
column14: I discuss this further below.

column1: You can go through a lot of trouble to save Melina by using the flame of frenzy and then Miquellas needle in the special area
column2: but you will still never see Melina again which is kinda lame considering how there's no other reason to get flame of frenzy early in the game.

column1: --| Elden Throne endings (Biggest letdown of the game)
At first the game had a lot of dialogue and npcs but slowly it just became another ds4. The endings for Elden Lord were especially disappointing
column2: very lackluster and similar
column3: like they could've at least had fia stand by your side as an apparition or melina after using miquellas needle. The only storytelling they did right was rannis questline where quest progression was clear and it unlocked new areas.

column1: When interacting with the world NPCs ask you to become their champion
column2: their elden lord and support their cause. You take allegiances with a side and progress their questline to get the ending they desire. However when you go through the trouble of completing their quest and reach their ending all you get is a lame cutscene which hardly shows the consequences of your actions or where the world is heading (and spoilers they all die
column3: just cause
column4: there's literally no one left who you supported). The endings could have been much better
column5: its really a shame that so much potential for great characters like fia and dung eater was wasted. The endings should have been more unique like Ranni's or Frenzy Flame
column6: seeing how the new ruling faction influences the world.

column1: In summary my main complaints are the npc questlines
column2: elden throne endings and lacking diversity as the game progresses. They botched some great characters big time in my opinion.";151.9;1.0;0.0;91.0;Posted: May 20

column2: first off
column3: this game is extremely good. The world is immersive and deceptively deep
column4: and the scale of this game is incredible. I don't just mean the size of the map
column5: but the incredible versatility of the environments and the sheer mass of buildings and geography are intense to say the least. It looks beautiful and plays like a dream. The gameplay is extremely polished
column6: and I don't think I've ever seen cleaner hit-boxes.

column2: this game is in SERIOUS need of balancing. I'm nowhere near the end of the game
column3: but I still get routinely 1/2-shotted by some bosses I'm definitely leveled enough for. I'm also in full heavy armor and using a shield with the Barricade Shield ability. Even so
column4: you'd think I wasn't playing a tank based on how much damage I take. Quite frankly
column5: it's absurd. It's not as if the game is too difficult
column6: but rather that the game is far too punishing for the tiniest of mistakes.

column1: This isn't a problem on all bosses though. Margit is a great example of a perfectly tuned and incredible fight
column2: assuming you approach the encounter without grinding too much (or too early
column3: for that matter). It's a fantastic skill check to see if you are ready for what the game has to offer.

column1: Not all bosses are as well tuned as Margit though. If you want to make a game difficult
column2: don't just crank up the damage the bosses deal and call it good. That's poor game design. A difficult encounter should push you to the limit of your skill and make you better at the game than you were before
column3: not just stun combo you into oblivion if you dodge 0.00001 seconds too early. It feels really cheap sometimes.

column1: I know this sort of critique is likely to licit 25 variations of ""git gud
column2: but this is the one and ONLY problem I have with the game.

column1: It's an astounding title and I can't wait to play it more
column2: I just wish the difficulty was more rewarding to an increase in skill rather than level.";102.4;1.0;0.0;50.0;Posted: May 18

column1: First of: Warning for players with AMD Graphic cards: the red lightning dragons can and most likely will crash your game. One solution seems to be to lower the graphics settings and try not to look at them (do not use lock on)
column2: use a summon and hope the enemy dies. Kind of ruins some of the bosses
column3: unfortunately. Hopefully they will fix it at some point.

column1: Apart from this: Its a fun game.

column2: depending on the build you can have a drastically different experience and difficulty.

column1: To make fights easier you can also use ash summons which is an interesting system
column2: I think. You can find the summons spread out in the world and its fun finding new ones.

column1: The levels and Legacy dungeons are fun
column2: the open world looks gorgeous
column3: but feels a bit stretched out at times.

column1: Recycled enemies get kind of boring after some time. Unfortunately there are also a lot of identical looking dungeons (catacombs and caves). That kind of sucks
column2: it doest take long to get tired of those layouts. also in late game caves previous bosses are used as normal enemies
column3: which can get really annoying since they also have really big health pools and killing them isnt rewarding.

column2: especially later on
column3: have very large health pools and deal insane amounts of damage
column4: even with relatively high vigor (>50) you can only survive a hand full of hits from enemies. Especially annoying for the reskinned soldiers/knights. However with them you can at least guess they will be stronger if they have a new colour. There are several enemies
column5: like crucible knights
column6: that look identical
column7: but have vastly different health pools
column8: which can get frustrating if you can not properly anticipate their strength beforehand.

column2: I wish it was less of an open world and more focused levels
column3: since those tend to be the best and most interesting. Like Sormveil castle
column4: the Academy or nokron eternal city.

column1: Despite the problems you can have fun with the game and its easy to respec the character if you feel like your build doesnt work or you want to try something else. Also: Dont try to see everything in the first playthrough
column2: I did this and all the identical catacombs with annoying enemies almost killed the game for me
column3: just do what is fun to you. There is a NG system
column4: so no need to 100% first playthrough.";181.8;1.0;0.0;369.0;Posted: May 20

Since there's no neutral option I'm going with neg to point out some of the games flaws. Some of what I say may have spoilers
column2: but I'll try not to add any. Overall I enjoy the game and will continue to play it off and on
column3: but this is definitely the weakest souls game From Software has made in my opinion.

column2: it's solid
column3: but it's the jankiest of any FS souls game I've played
column4: has multiple glitches
column5: and the open world mechanics clash and weaken what I personally like about the souls games
column6: like a sense of achievement or reward. I went through my first time cold
column7: then my second time with a guide to comb through. I've been through a third since then
column8: and I've tried out about 2 builds per char.

column2: on PC at least. Summoning errors that have not been corrected since launch that only seem to effect a certain group of people (https://tinyurl.com/42rhh6nt) Body/rune recovery glitches
column3: broken quests (still) inaccurate stat scaling on multiple accounts (some fixed) Getting attacked through walls is way worse than it's ever been before - enemies and bosses read inputs as a cheap mechanism to kill you.

column1: -Overall I died more in this game to being overrun with surprise enemies than in any other souls game - being jumped and surrounded and stun locked seems to be the main thing in this game. As long as you are patient and use target lock there's not much of a challenge outside of a boss room or two.
-as for BOSSES - so many are reused it's sad. some of the main bosses are re-used over and over again in the open world dungeons
column2: which are quite often the same layout
column3: and just feel like weak busy work and excuses to kill time. Most can be completed in less than 10 minutes. a couple few may give you a challenge and last 30.

column2: that obscure souls quest system was fun and great in the more funneled design of the previous souls games. Having NPCS randomly move around such a large open world makes some quests impossible to understand without a guide.

column1: -While a a previous Dark Souls game may offer you multiple paths to take
column2: you'd always inevitably hit a boss you need to handle
column3: sometimes leaving you stuck between a rock and a hard place until you figured it out. The sense of accomplishment from this situation is gone
column4: since now you can run around the open world and level and gear to your hearts content. Without killing the first MINI boss
column5: you can comb every single area of the game minus a small handful of end game areas
column6: which only require 2 boss kills. The result is a lot of well geared invaders at lower levels stomping people. There's also no level cap on weapon buffs like the old games
column7: so a level 5 char can rock an end game +25 sword and invade your beginning char. This could happen in previous souls games
column8: but it took skill to pass the boss gates at the low levels to get that gear to invade. Not anymore.

column1: -The lack of design in the open world can be plainly seen
column2: and is mostly there as a huge time waster. There's not much reason to the day/night cycle besides some hidden bosses and some enemies may drop a small amount more of runes. The stealth mechanics are laughably OP and the AI is totally blind making free stealth damage a constant no matter what your build. A lot off items I'd usually just be able to buy from a vendor over and over with souls/runes are now replaced with crafting system crap I need to waste time to farm up instead. If you get invaded in the open world might as well just sit and wait for 5 minutes for the idiot to come running towards you lol. Just a lot of weakness in what I was expecting to be tighter gameplay.

column1: Overall this game is the worst where it strays from it's traditional design
column2: the open world is weak
column3: almost everything about it is a boring addition
column4: or weakens the strength of the souls formula
column5: I think it's a good first attempt
column6: but my hope in the future is they do more legacy type areas and far less open world areas
column7: the lack of having a funneled design in a lot of the open worlds places makes it weak
column8: exploitable
column9: and overall less enjoyable.";243.0;0.0;2.0;313.0;Posted: May 22

column1: TLDR: Search on youtube ""let me solo her Malena"". That's the game in a nut shell. If you like what you see then you will enjoy this game (controller is a must however).

Kind of a 3D Mortal Combat arcade fighting game (extensive twitch muscle memory when mashing buttons is a must) with very light RPG elements and lots of exploration (this is were the Asian culture of the developer comes out) though very much of it is repetitive. It's essentially a console game that works quite poorly on PC (don't even attempt using a keyboard and mouse - as a matter of fact the game's input tool-tips by default assume you are using a controller).

The combat has a bunch of contrived mechanics slapped together that are probably in place to account for the limitations of a console controller (can't control vision and also hit XYBA buttons at the same time - I am using a steam controller - etc.). As a side note
column2: I don't play console games because I find the controllers subpar compared to a keyboard and mouse.

column1: Veterans of PC FPS games are REALLY going to struggle with the camera movement
column2: the controls and the combat mechanics. Be prepared to forget everything you know and learn something you will only use in the ""FromSoft"" games. There's nothing else quite like it on the PC market and that's probably for a very good reason.

column1: You got stuff like rolling (dodging) into mob abilities and take no damage as long as you do it at the right time (they call this immunity frames)
column2: you can jump to avoid some ground aoe (even though the particle effects clearly engulf you visually) and so on. In addition there's some very sadistic input requirements some are just stupid some are likely driven by the use of the controller. For example to dodge in a specific direction you have to hold down the direction button for at least a second BEFORE pressing the dodge button
column3: and to run you have to press and hold the dodge button for at least a second - all this in a game were dodging/sprinting in the right direction at the right millisecond is vital. I thought maybe they are trying to simulate inertia and mass
column4: but that's not the case as you (and mobs) can do a 180 turn on a pin head when rolling or running when using the mouse.

column1: And then there is dodging. Lots of It as Boss combos can be very long (6-7 moves or more). This game should really be called Elden Dodge. Yes there's stuff like parry and blocking but their usage is extremely limited when fighting a boss (again mainly because of the length of the combos). A boss fight consists of 3-4
column2: up to 8 or even more consecutive very well timed dodges followed by one swing. Rinse and repeat until boss is dead.

there is essentially no character customization in terms of stats. As a matter of fact it really doesn't matter what class you start with as they will end up identical if/when you max all their stats. Spells
column3: weapons and armor cannot be customized in any way (you do have 5-6 types of arrow damage and more arrows that do same type of damage just more of it). Weapons can be upgraded (it's a straight forward damage buff) and can be tweaked with abilities (called ashes of war). There are lots of weapons but for the most part only a handful of classes (15 weapon classes or so?). The class gives the weapon it's move set (what it does when you swing it). Each weapon can have up to 1 ability. Most do come with one. An ash of war allows you to change that one ability and also change the damage type (and the stat with which the damage scales
column4: but it's not really important).

column1: Quests are limited (this is no way an Elder Scrolls Game). The story and characters are very Asian. The lore is definitely something to behold as GRR Martin (he got hired for this game) is a master lore builder
column2: but a complete failure when it comes to story telling (that's why he keeps killing all his characters in his books
column3: because he can't tell a story to save his life and he needs to make room for new characters and the lore surrounding them).

column1: There is a lot of fake hype surrounding this game. Going in I heard stuff like ""best mounted combat in any game ever"" etc. Don't be mistaken
column2: this game's combat mechanics cannot begin to compare with stuff you find in titles like ""For Honor"" or ""Mount & Blade"". And what it has is weird
column3: contrived
column4: awkward
column5: going into a direction all of its own. And just another example of how awful and contrived the controls of this game are (again probably driven by the fact that the input scheme is designed for a console controller): You cannot turn your mount around AND stand put in a given spot (say atop a cliff). Not with your normal controls. You CAN do it IF you use an item (looking glass) which provides zoom vision. In an exploration game... where cliffs and falling are an important mechanics.";45.6;0.0;1.0;99.0;Posted: May 21

column1: So this is a full priced AAA 2022 game which has:
* PC controls which would not be considered acceptable even in the 1980s. (Even though you can rebind the keys
column2: this game was designed exclusively for a PS controller
column3: not a mouse/keyboard - so for instance
column4: the F key by default jumps - because that's how insane the PC controls are.)

column1: * UI design which would also not be considered be acceptable even in the 1990s
* Loading screen which shows a message box you have to click ""Accept"" on every time you go to the main menu. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME.
* Graphics which would be considered cutting edge back in 2006.

column2: but not one which you can actually follow. I finished it and as far as I can tell there's a ring (maybe? it's in the title of the game - but never seen it) and eventually <spoiler>you kill the ruler/god of the land and I guess that means you're in charge?</spoiler> I don't think I finished a single NPC's questline - and there were about 50 of them. I mean you could if you really
column3: really wanted
column4: but you'd have to Google how to do it and then follow the instructions exactly - if you deviate
column5: the questline just ends - with no notification whatsoever. While there is a map (thank god - the world is huge)
column6: only < 1% of the questlines actually put locations that you're supposed to go to on this map - to the extent that if you see a location marked on your map - you think it's a bug.

column1: * Intentionally annoying level design - which just consumes your time - but neither adds difficulty nor is fun. (You will die 500ish times in the course of playing this game - and each time
column2: you'll burn about 10s on a loading screen
column3: and then 20s-120s just running back to start the boss fight again). So that's about 20h of your life wasted.

column1: Welcome to a FromSoftware port on PC.";132.0;0.0;1.0;55.0;Posted: May 22

I've played what I consider to be a decent amount of the game. Got about as far as Leyndell before deciding I'd had enough of the nonsense. Elden Ring is far and away from being a good game. A beautiful-yet-boring world stuffed with repetitive filler to make the game look like there's a lot of content when really it's just copy/pasted enemies filling in a pretty backdrop. No joke
column2: that's all you do: run around a big empty world and kill enemies and even bigger enemies. Oh
column3: and die a lot.

column2: this game is difficult. Yes
column3: I went into this knowing that FromSoftware games are notoriously hard. I didn't think I'd mind that because I love a good challenge. But there's a HUGE different between being difficult and being straight-up immersion-breaking. And Elden Ring is a whole lot of the latter. Enemies and bosses can one- or two-shot you even if you've leveled up a significant amount. Even if you've gotten better weapons or upgraded your existing ones. Even if you went and found an NPC or Ashes of War or even another player to summon to your aid. No matter how many hours you spend grinding runes. No matter how many times you try to parry or dodge or heal or even cheese
column4: all of which are at many times impossible to do because the enemies and bosses are just too fast and too unpredictable. At some point they've killed you so many times that it becomes more of a chore than a game.

column2: which in and of itself is virtually nonexistent and should more or less be labeled ""loreytelling"". There's a ton of exposition in the beginning cutscene
column3: and then you're just told to go become Elden Lord. No reason why
column4: just go do it because that's the game. But beyond that
column5: there's no unfolding
column6: driven narrative. No characters worth giving a crap about. No plot twists or emotional moments or anything that makes the player WANT to continue. All there is is worldbuilding and an egregious amount of it that most people will probably miss. The game doesn't even tell you what the purpose of any of this is. WHY do I need to claim the title of Elden Lord? WHY is the Erdtree important and not simply the biggest freaking MacGuffin I've ever laid eyes on? WHAT is the point?

column1: I don't particularly care what excuses anyone has defending this game's insulting lack of story. Lore and story are two very different things
column2: not interchangeable synonyms. If Elden Ring were a novel
column3: it'd be one of the worst-written novels I've ever heard of.

column1: The last major issue I have with this game is the dungeon design. Maybe I'm spoiled by the dungeons of Zelda
column2: but these ""dungeons"" are little more than fortresses filled with a ton of enemies and little else. Whether it's the big main dungeons or the smaller castles or even the stuff underground
column3: everything is routinely the same. The big dungeons at least have different visual appearances to them
column4: but there's so few of them compared to the tons of copy-pasted smaller dungeons that it almost doesn't matter. None of these dungeons are memorable in any sense of the word.

column1: The only real aspects of Elden Ring that I can confidently consider pros are the gorgeous graphics and the stellar soundtrack. If even half as much effort went into making the rest of the game that good
column2: I wouldn't be as upset at it. But in no conceivable way can I recommend this game. It just does not live up to the hype surrounding it.";40.2;0.0;2.0;101.0;Posted: May 23

column2: which I appreciate. But a few choices make it kind of irritating. I never know what the heck I'm supposed to do. Many other large
column3: open world games have some kind of quest tracking system
column4: typically integrated with the map. I've got over 30 hours into the game and I don't know if I'm working toward the main story or not. The artwork is intricate and highly stylized
column5: but seems too whimsical for me. Everything has a fairy tale
column6: dreamlike quality. It's also clearly designed for consoles. I purchased the steam version for PC and literally wasn't able to get through character creation since by default all the controls are for console. I needed to Google instructions to change the defaults to use keyboard and mouse. Is it so hard for the devs to make the PC version default to using PC for input? It seems more like the game designers just don't care about the player's convenience or happiness. The quick slot system makes it very hard on PC to change between for example sometimes using a bow and sometimes using a sword and shield combo. Finally there's no way to pause the game. column1: I want to love this game but it has some very glaring issues that make me unable to recommend it. The boss design is terrible
column2: some of the worst in any game I've played ranging from bosses that do extremely long
column3: almost impossible to avoid combos that end in delayed AoEs so melee players can't get in
column4: or the boss will fly completely across a huge map constantly so you're chasing and dodging for an eternity hoping to get 1 hit in or the boss is made that you can only attack if you take damage but all the bosses hit like a nuke
column5: even with full vigor most bosses can take half your health in 1 hit
column6: but ranged players aren't home free either
column7: there are bosses that are completely resistant to magic
column8: story bosses that are immune or heal from things like holy damage so if you tried to make a faith build around holy damaging weapons or spells
column9: your journey ends here because that story boss is completely immune to you and the fight would be hard already for a build that can actually damage it with their best stuff. The worst part is
column10: the worst offenders of the bad design issue are mandatory story bosses
column11: like a certain someone who's name rhymes with Margaret or the star that shall not be named
column12: if you played the game more than a few hours you know. There are also lots of dungeons that lock you in with no way to get out but fighting
column13: no indication on the level or anything so exploring
column14: it is entirely possible to end up stuck somewhere with no way to get out because you're not strong enough to fight
column15: including a trap right in the starting area that could very easily have you stuck if you don't know the path to get out. then you add in bad patches where they remove access to upgrades or things that just made certain mandatory encounters manageable on all builds while leaving in extremely bad things that some bosses can do that they very clearly shouldn't and the community complains about nonstop
column16: or things like PvP that is awful and you're left with a fun but fatally flawed game. It has a lot of good but when the worst part of a Souls game is the bosses
column17: there is a big issue.";152.4;0.0;3.0;8.0;Posted: May 17
