I've played 0.6hrs at time of review and it is not looking good. If a game goes not hook me from the start and give me that feeling i'm too old to bother with it. Entertainment should not be a chore I have to work for in the hope of maybe I will be entertained at a later date..

column1: The game intro is a series of 2d still drawing with voiceover. There are lots of words and images that mean nothing
column2: are nonsensical
column3: explain nothing and do absolutely nothing to hook you and get you pumped for the game. The only reason I can come up with is if someone thought this was a way to create mystery
column4: is a drunk guys rambles mysterious er no. If this was the aim they should have just started the game
column5: no intro just dump you in the world
column6: that would create some mystery. Or get someone with some talent in to make a good intro.

column1: Ok you start the game and by now some voiceover has said you want to find this ring. I don't know who I am or why I want it
column2: no back story nothing
column3: how do I know I even want it? Who knows maybe a guy in a pub said it would look nice on me. Saying my character wants something with no context is not mystery guys it is just dumb.

column1: You find messages str8 away everywhere that mean nothing and are nonsensical

column2: feel free to inform me so. Now to the review.

column1: This game is a waste of potential. It takes the fantastic concept of challenging bosses that make you feel godly and are extremely rewarding upon their defeat and removes the ""make you feel godly part"". Ill compare this to hollow knight(Hence
column2: spoilers for hollow knight ahead) since these 2 games share some very similar ending sequences: Radagon-Elden Beast and Hollow Knight-Radiance

you first have to fight a stupidly unbalanced boss that will hit you with carbon molecules he exhaled from his ass before being able to fight a boss that will keep a distance of 9 marathons from you all while spamming so many projectiles you forget what a projectile even is. Whenever you die you have to go through the stupidly unbalanced boss every time
column3: effectively draining everything you have-potions
column4: summons
column5: you name it
column6: before putting you in another fight.

column1: Now the game I draw comparison to: Hollow Knight. In it
column2: you follow a very similar formula: fight a boss to reach the other one
column3: have to refight the entrance boss every time you die. Now here is the magic of hollow knight: the fight isnt overly challenging in comparison to other fights in the game. The fight is actually very well balanced-all the attacks are perfectly manageable(Im looking at you
column4: Radagon's 10 mile long hammer slam hit-you-with-his-ass hitboxes). Beyond that
column5: Hollow Knight
column6: too
column7: has an invincibility-roll kind of mechanic with it's dashes at that point in the game. So what makes the fight different? Literally everything. Hollow Knight is there(in my opinion
column8: I know a lot of people see it as a big flaw) to make YOU feel hollow. The fight is simple-its just a gate to get to the final boss. If you die to the final boss once
column9: it feels like a punishment
column10: after all
column11: chances are
column12: you got your ass kicked into nothing by the Hollow Knight
column13: but you get progressively better and better at it to the point where you feel like a god
column14: until eventually you fight him so many times the feeling fades away and you are fully focused on defeating radiance
column15: at which point it is you successfully ""contain"" it. Now what happens in Elden Ring in the same exact scenario: you are alive by a single strand of hp with 4 potions as you go into the final boss
column16: you die. You then die to Radagon 7 more times before getting to the boss again
column17: you die. You eventually get good enough where you beat him consistently but it kind of stops there for your average Joe. You get your ass kicked over and over and over. If this is a roleplaying game the role you are playing is the victim of abuse. When I finally defeated the Elden Beast I didnt get a feeling of ""HELL YEAH FINALLY"" like I did with the radiance
column18: rather it was ""finally this fat ♥♥♥♥ is dead"". It felt like a burden. In case you cant see the issue here-Hollow Knight(the boss
column19: not the game itself) was BUILT to be a burden and yet felt 10x less of a burden than whatever the hell Elden Ring has going. And dont even get me started on how bleed-a whole major build type-was disabled in its entirety on the fight. I could draw many more similar examples-Malenia and Mantis lords(both fast paced and very punishing fights) for example. And don't even get me started on the quests here. They are so horrible they dont deserve to be spoken of. Basically the main issue is how unbalanced boss battles are(took the challenging for the sake of challenging path instead of challenging for the sake of rewarding path)

I respect the business practices and all the art that went into this game. I think there are truly excellent parts. It's very repetitive
column2: the bosses are mostly unremarkable or unfair or simply annoying and the RPG elements are weaker than they've been in a Souls game in years. I can't recommend this game because it didn't make me feel anything new and was boring or annoying for the vast majority of the runtime.
there are so many dungeons smattered throughout the world that are caves
column3: catacombs
column4: mines
column5: etc. There are a few truly special ones
column6: but once you've beaten one of the generic ones
column7: you've beaten all of them. This system feels significantly worse than the much maligned chalice dungeons. Since the dungeons in Elden Ring are finite
column8: I felt a desire or hope to find something really interesting and unique in them. Instead
column9: they generally provide summons or weapons that were almost always useless. Without any extrinsic benefit
column10: you'd hope that they'd be fun. Unfortunately
column11: none of the dungeons provide satisfying puzzles and many of the bosses are just regular enemies from elsewhere put with a big health bar. Chalice dungeons had unique and good bosses
column12: extrinsic benefits that couldn't be gotten anywhere else
column13: and were a good mix of repetitive and challenging. This new dungeon system is a step backwards in most ways.

column1: That's just one area of this game that really shows its weaknesses. There's too much content with a lack of originality and specialness. There's so much good here spread out with long open plains and peppered with crap to fill the world. Compared with the games from Ubisoft and their ilk
column2: this is a triumph with commendable business practices and tons of wonderful elements. I think FromSoftware has released significantly better games in the past (Demon's Souls
column3: Dark Souls 1

column1: It’s no secret that Elden Ring has gained A LOT of praise. Besides the buggy launch with performance issues (welcome to the gaming industry for the last 15 years)
column2: most people have only great things to say about it. I’m more in the mixed camp.

column1: For the first time in the Souls series from Software
column2: it’s fun to use mage build. It’s VERY flexible and you have so many spells (if you can find them) to play around with. The Spirits is also a good addition if you lack co-op help.
while I do enjoy most of the game I also have gripes with it. But none of it makes it a silly super low score.

column1: The Easy Anti Cheat is really pointless and network stability when doing invading or co-op is unstable. Somehow this has gotten worse since Dark Souls 3. Which is weird. I do hope FromSoftware does a better job on online play in the future because it REALLY needs work. Framerate is still unstable and I’m sure if it’s the old game engine or the damn awful AC implementation used.
I know OPEN WORLD is very popular. Sadly Elden Ring’s map feels more like something from a Ubisoft game. By the end
column2: you have so many icons on the map that it’s ridiculous. Also
column3: the many mini-dungeons are really BORING. I know the previous games had smaller environments because of the consoles. But it also just worked pretty well for the games. Everything felt connected. I don’t feel that with Elden Ring.

column1: - The lock-on system is still awful and they REALLY need to update it with their next game as well.
- Unless you are hardcore and have A LOT of time
column2: good luck finding and understanding most things in the game without online guides. Some of these quests are old-school Nintendo Castlevania ♥♥♥♥ and not that interesting. Of course
column3: this is not new to the Souls series.

column1: For me the game is a 3/5 Stars

column6: stay away.

column1: I'm not wholly unenthusiastic--the art direction and visual style is good
column2: and if they fixed the numerous things I am about to list below as the problems I had
column3: then I would genuinely enjoy the combat. I'm also told that previous games by this publisher used to be even less accessible
column4: so progress
column5: kind of
column6: I guess?

column1: But there are a lot of flaws I've already butted into with only a few hours of playtime (anyone who wants to tell me to ""git gud"" or similar should be aware there is a special circle of Hell for those who demand people treat their leisure time like a job).
--Co op with friends comes with mandatory PvP attackers you cannot opt out of. Also
column2: no form of scaling is available to make co op with higher level friends more functional if you are starting out.

column1: --Currency and XP are the same thing
column2: and both are lost on death. You can theoretically reclaim them
column3: but only within a limited window
column4: and there is no bank. Period.

column2: in addition to the loss of resources already mentioned
column3: you may not be able to get to the enemy that killed you to learn how to better deal with them for a while
column4: because pulling too many enemies at once will just murder you so you need to approach every fight cautiously--and therefore time-consumingly. Add to this that the theoretically great build variety comes with all sorts of animation details you need to learn
column5: and you're going to be spending a lot of time in loading screens and carefully approaching enemy camps and the like.

column1: --There are no difficulty settings of any kind
column2: which would be a thing that would allow the good of the game to shine through without making it disrespect the player's time availability nearly so much.
this is a game I very much want to like and simply cannot. More power to those who can
column3: but I want to warn those who like me
column4: were tempted by the acclaim into thinking it might be a decent casual dip of a game
column5: rather than a lifestyle you adopt for months.

column1: Addendum: I was able to do a ton of external research and conversations with friends and get to the point where I am enjoying the game now. I stand by my original review
column2: however
column3: as the game should not require that level of external resource use.";55.8;0.0;3.0;92.0;Posted: May 16

column1: What could have been a truly amazing co-op experience is unfortunately hindered by one of the worst co-op multiplayer systems implemented in a game to date. Progress is not saved for both players
column2: meaning you have to run all bosses and objectives twice. The player being summoned will also be de-summoned after every single boss event and/or after either of the two players die. This means that throughout even a short play session you'll have to spend tons of time just re-summoning your friend
column3: over and over and over
column4: ad nauseam. It doesn't add anything meaningful to the gameplay cycle
column5: and I struggle to see why they chose this system over literally any other more viable option. Finally
column6: you'll spend lots of time struggling against invading PvP players (that you cannot disable). Now
column7: I don't mind PvP in games (although I would of course prefer to at least have the option to choose)
column8: but when the vast majority of encounters are with players using either cheats to win or to brick your game (yes
column9: that's a thing
column10: they can ruin your save file by using altered items)
column11: then the whole gameplay experience takes a hard turn for the worse.";91.2;0.0;2.0;298.0;Posted: May 22

column1: I would explain why I don't like this game
column2: but fanboys will just say ""git gud"" to ignore any problems that may exist within the game.

column1: First of I want to say that I've played tons of souls and souls-like games. With that in mind
column2: I'm extremely divided with my experience with this game and here's why.

column1: I'll start off with the positives; the first third or half if we're being generous are downright magical
column2: especially the first 20-30 hours or so. For me
column3: time flew by
column4: I stayed up all night exploring
column5: killing tough bosses
column6: finding out all sorts of great secrets and just had myself a blast. Open world and Dark Souls works surprisingly well...or so I thought
column7: but more on that later.

column1: The overall atmosphere of the game is also great and it looks gorgeous. Visuals have always been one of the better selling points of Souls-games in my opinion and they nailed that once again. Many areas in the game are as fun to look at as they are to explore and they were for the most part fairly creative with them. Exploring them is also pretty fun
column2: although that again diminishes over time in my opinion; last third being exceptionally boring if you ask me.

column1: One double-edged sword for me is the variety given to player to tackle the many enemies that the Lands Between throws at you. While variety is the spice of life and I'm a big spicy food enthusiast
column2: I think this time it might have gone a bit too far. I'm the completionist type who likes to explore everything
column3: which I did during my playthrough of the game; I explored every area
column4: every dungeon
column5: beat every boss
column6: got every possible rune to get whatever ending I desired. The issue is that many of the items you get
column7: you will just not use
column8: which diminishes the eagerness to explore. Spells are good example of this; there are dozens of them in the game
column9: but if you're playing a melee build
column10: which is the most common way to play these games
column11: you will most likely not use them all that much
column12: or mostly a selected handful that boost your combat effectiveness. Still
column13: I enjoyed the exploring overall
column14: but this aspect of it did suffer as a result.

column1: Many weapons you get might be hard to upgrade with lacking materials
column2: so once you find what works for you
column3: you're not likely to change
column4: unless to have a backup weapon or two in case you want something specific
column5: like bleed damage for example. Never before has there been an option to get so over-powered so easily
column6: which I feel takes much charm out of the experience.

column1: The last third of the game for me was a slog
column2: with any battle be it just normal foe or boss being challenging in a fun way; most of them I could beat after few tries
column3: some of which I didn't even get to hear all of the dialogue. The element of summon spirits is also fuels this much more. Code Vein
column4: also Souls-like game
column5: also had co-op character as integral part of it's design and in that game the difficulty of it was still well maintained. Sadly
column6: I can't say the same for Elden Ring. One spirit summon in particular is notorious and most people who have beaten the game know what I'm talking about. Some people would say that you don't have to use it
column7: which is true
column8: but summon spirits are a game mechanic the game very heavily promotes
column9: be it through upgrades
column10: sheer amount of them you can get and how many of the bosses are seemingly made with one (or more) additional character on your side. Them taking the attention away from you
column11: taking away the one versus one nail biting gameplay the series is known for to me is maybe the single biggest miss with this game. This is the most accessible game From Software has ever done
column12: but I think it has come at too big of a cost. Much like horror movies
column13: to me difficulty of the experience is just part of it's foundation; by default
column14: some people aren't going to like it
column15: and that's okay. With them trying to please everyone
column16: ultimately it feels like the opposite of desired effect was reached

column1: Outside of the issues with the bosses and their design
column2: the second biggest flaw that really hindered my enjoyment of the game is oddly enough the open world nature of the game. Since the player is fairly free to explore the areas in whatever order they desire
column3: it is fairly easy to end up being too low level for a certain area and being too high level for another. Since Souls-games don't exactly show you what level you ought to be for any area (which I think is good
column4: mind you
column5: we don't need these games to be Ubisoft clones)
column6: it made some areas extremely boring.

column2: I visited the Raya Lucaria Academy fairly late
column3: after I had beaten Volcano Manor. Volcano Manor was maybe the single best experience to me in the game; the entire area oozed with atmosphere
column4: was challenging
column5: with memorable characters
column6: enemies and bosses. Were everything about the game to this level
column7: I would have given this game two thumbs up for sure. When I entered Raya Lucaria Academy afterwards
column8: it was absolute cakewalk. During my run
column9: I think I died maybe two or three times and that was mostly due to falling
column10: not because of enemies. I'm also by no means the most amazing gamer out there
column11: despite being Souls veteran
column12: but I was simply way too high of a level to the area. I really wish there was some sort of scaling option in the game to keep the areas challenging
column13: but without it the enjoyment for me was ruined almost completely when I never had to learn the boss moves and patterns
column14: as simply going to their face and smacking them did the trick.

column1: I also think that the game is too big for it's own good. To me this is maybe heightened the most by the absolutely insane amount of bosses being recycled in the game. There are total of 9 truly unique boss fights in the game
column2: with everything else being copies of at least one another boss one way or another. Some bosses you will see so many times that they lose all of their magic
column3: like dragons or magma wyrms for example; both fights that were initially extremely fun
column4: challenging and memorable
column5: but by 5th time you can't help but to your roll your eyes. I would have much preferred if they had cut out chunks of the game
column6: like the snowy area towards the end to make the rest of the experience tighter
column7: more narrowed
column8: focused and unique.

column1: I quickly also want to mention riding and crafting. I was fairly neutral on both of these personally. I didn't use crafting all that much
column2: with exception of ailment items and pots for the most part. There were tons and tons of recipes
column3: but more often than not there was no need for them
column4: at least not for me personally. This is maybe because gathering resources was tedious when you're not riding past a field of them or when exploring a cave. Not a bad concept
column5: but I still felt like it wasn't utilized properly either
column6: but certainly didn't ruin the game for me either.

column2: I quite enjoyed the horse combat. I liked it when especially when fighting the dragons as you could dodge the breath attacks and quickly catch up with them. Overall though I feel like this system too was a bit underutilized. This might be a personal taste thing
column3: but to me Souls games are still better without it. Again
column4: a hit and miss feature in my eyes.

column2: this is the first Souls game I struggled having to finish. The highs of the game are very much up there
column3: the first third or half of the game is truly a magical experience
column4: definitely worth both the time and money I put into it. As the game progresses
column5: however
column6: the magic fades away and you're left with big
column7: yet empty feeling world. The numerous issues that seem to go up against the very core design the series is both know and loved for makes this a bitter soup to swallow. I can't say that I hated my time with the game
column8: but I can't say that I wholeheartedly enjoyed it either. I hope that despite the insane success of this title that From Software takes few steps back to inspect their work before starting the next project. If their next game repeats most of the things that were in the Elden Ring
column9: it might be my very first purposeful pass for the series. And as someone who really loves these games
column10: I hope that won't be the case.";135.9;0.0;3.0;596.0;Posted: May 21

Elden Ring is a poorly optimized console port that is ruined by the forced install of Easy Anti-Cheat. If you prefer not to play games that are excessively difficult and that have the Dark Souls formula of saving only at bonfires with respawning enemies and way too many difficult boss battles then this game is NOT for you. Easy Anti-Cheat causes the game not to work with ANY trainer and it can also cause the game to even stop loading. There is also no campaign or true levels. You just wonder around from boss fight to boss fight with no idea if you are making any progress or not. I also could not play this game in 4k resolution because of constant frame rate drops. 1080p looks grainy and I was still getting frame rate drops using an RTX2080 and i9 processor. There is also no resolution slider and all of the game commands and instructions are for a controller and not a keyboard. I seriously regretted this purchase and promptly refunded.";0.7;0.0;0.0;118.0;Posted: May 19

column2: I can say this is my least favorite game from FROMSOFTWARE. Now this is completely personal and I expect people to disagree
column3: that's fine
column4: but I'll still explain why I think this is their worst game. (Note that I have not played Demon's Souls or Bloodborne because I'm not buying a Playstation just for those games. I only cleared DS1 once but cleared DS2
column5: DS3 and Sekiro multiple times each
column6: so I don't think this is a ""git gud"" issue.)

column1: The two main problems I have with the game are parts of the open world and the (not always but way too often) godawful enemy design.
The open world is beautiful and offers lots of options to the player
column2: which at first glance is very nice right ? Well
column3: it turns out that this same open worlds comes in to butcher what other souls games have been pretty great at executing : difficulty progression. Yes
column4: in other games you could stumble upon an area you were not supposed to clear yet and get destroyed by the enemies in there
column5: but there was a limited set of possibilities in terms of new areas that were accessible to you at a time. In Elden Ring however
column6: you have infinite possibilities. Therefore
column7: the pattern that starts to occur when you enter a new area is ""Either I wreck everything in here or they wreck me"". This makes for a mediocre experience at best because if something is too hard
column8: you just walk out and go somewhere else until you find something you can actually clear. The fact that the game is so open also doesn't really fit a souls game. Maybe that's just me ? I feel like exploring should be sort of relaxing and laid back but then you find some cool ruins and you need to activate tryhard

column1: mode to clear it. Kinda breaks the rythm of the game in my opinion. Also it kinda kills one of my favorite aspects from the Dark Souls series : the claustrophobia inducing level design. (Obviously we can still find that in the legacy dungeons which are AMAZING in both presentation and level design. There's a reason why those are by far my favorite part of the game.)
Now on the topic of the enemy design
column2: it's been pointed out a lot already but I've heard that the enemy design was very inspired by Bloodborne enemies. You'll remember from earlier that I did NOT play Bloodborne but I did play Sekiro and I'd say that some enemies very much do feel like they were taken straight out of Sekiro and slapped into Elden Ring with no adjustments whatsoever while WE only have a DS1 moveset at our disposal. Some of them are just way too fast
column3: some of them keep on attacking for so long you can grow a 6ft long beard before they stop and some do both. This makes for some of the most frustrating encounters I've had in any game I've played and
column4: mostly for that reason alone
column5: I think this game is way
column6: way worse than all their previous games. Also don't get me started on double boss fights. It's like they picked out the pairings at random.

column2: the open world is insanely gorgeous and very fun to explore
column3: but there's still this weird feeling that the game shouldn't switch from ""pleasant exploration"" to ""absolute sweatfest"" in an instant
column4: but then again it's not THAT big of an issue. The real problem really resides in the enemy design which is really flawed in certain areas of the game. I sometimes feel like I was given a toothpick to go fight a tank. That's unfortunately not something I can enjoy.

column1: I'm interested to hear your opinions. Are they different ? Do you agree with some of my points ?
Sorry for the wall of text but I think that rounds up everything. Have a good one !";67.6;0.0;14.0;409.0;Posted: 16 May

After ungodly amounts of hours in Souls games
column2: I've come to realize I don't quite enjoy playing these sorts of games anymore
column3: and Elden Ring only exacerbates everything that turned me away from the series in the first place. Is it the sacred cows that pervades throughout all the games? Perhaps it's the pastiche of poorly realized action and RPG mechanics that only seem to blend together because the systems lack any sort of depth in the first place. Or just maybe
column4: it's because it revels in this sort of mean-spirited
column5: emotionally manipulative design
column6: tacitly inserting brain worms telling you the dopamine pay-off of playing a ""hard game"" more than makes up for the impotent rage it'll definitely put you through
column7: no matter how terrible
column8: or lazy
column9: or unfair
column10: or God forbid unfun the challenges you'll face ahead are.

column1: Why should I even care about fighting the screetards (See: Royal Revenants)
column2: or the Runebears that are more vicious and more durable than 90% of the game's bosses
column3: or the late game enemies which are actually mobs recycled from early game content and refurbished with just enough stat bloat to 3-4 shot (in some cases 1-2) an appropriately leveled Tarnished
column4: all of which exist solely to make a mockery of my Demigod slayer's amazing feats that would pit him in the annals as an incredible hero of legends? My character never feels stronger
column5: or more competent at any point
column6: the only thing that improves is my skill as a player. Now this would normally be fine
column7: if I wasn't granted the delusion of playing a ROLE-PLAYING GAME
column8: and it would be fine if for all the loot and skills I acquire I was granted some kind of meaningful sense of progression so I'm better suited to deal with the stronger foes of Elden Ring
column9: but it never comes. From level 8 to 150 or so
column10: I'm equally equipped to deal with Revenants. If this game is a ""true RPG""
column11: then so is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Castlevania Symphony of the Night. Actually I take it back
column12: even SotN has a more satisfying progression curve than ER.

column1: Do I even need to go into the horrendous boss design of this game either? It's garbage
column2: not just the bosses themselves (most of them do suck however)
column3: but the combat and movement itself leaves so much to be desired
column4: tying into the original point about underutilized RPG and action mechanics I brought up earlier. These are the devs that made Bloodborne and Sekiro and we're STILL relying on roll-based movement in this high fantasy epic? What's even the point of the backstep? The new jump mechanic isn't innovation
column5: it's a basic feature for any game that doesn't take pride in being ""antiquated"" in its design philosophy like the Souls series does. Seriously
column6: am I the only one who thinks it's absurd you're rolling around in heavy armor just as much as a cloth-garbed Wizard would?

column1: You know what else? I don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about Elden Ring's World
column2: I don't care about the characters
column3: the grand choices that'll define the shape of The Lands Between itself
column4: the DEEP LORE!!! either
column5: it's all just ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Dark Souls. Same old Dark Souls and it's gloomy nihilistic themes of ""regeneration and degeneration uoOOoooH""
column6: this time with a corprophiliac fantasy writer from New Jersey on board. It's all so banal. That's the real problem of this game
column7: it brings nothing new to the table. It's pure kitsch
column8: even the reviews reflect this; emphasis on ""hard satisfying gameplay that doesn't hold the player's hand"" or ""an open world without quest markers blaring in your face""
column9: all of which says little about the quality of the game itself.

column1: Elden ring is like going through a maze with a blind fold on while people hit you in the face with baseball bats. The little bit of story there is in the game tends to have many steps to it and very little of it has any guidance
column2: expect extensive use of Google. If the game actually tried to have a meaningful story
column3: other than a general idea of one
column4: it could have been enjoyable enough to justify the purchase for me but as it stands it was a waste.

column1: - Graphics are about average for current games (character creation is an exception).

column2: while most often frustrating can be fun sometimes.

column1: - The builds and leveling seem rewarding and can be interesting.
- Finding something interesting or a secret area can often be an enjoyable experience.
- Mods made the game playable for me. I shouldn't have to mod a game to make it enjoyable
column2: at least it's not terribly difficult to do.

column1: - The characters you meet in the game are mostly shallow
column2: not well written or have any real effort put into them. After 70 hours of play
column3: I haven't found any character I care about or care what they have to say.

column1: - Very little direction as to where to go and what to do
column2: some see this as a positive but I don't because the only way to find out your in the wrong place is to get your face beat in and keep getting your face beat in until you find a place where you don't get smashed(or google it). Wander aimlessly around until you find something interesting and repeat that until you can get through one of the areas where you previously got your face beat in.

column1: - Character creation is clunky and out dated. Women don't really look like women
column2: they look like ugly men with boobs. It feels like the designers forgot to have women in the game and added the option last minute?

column1: - Can't figure out where to go to get that thing you need to progress to the next area? Google. Can't figure out where to find that weapon or armor you need? Google. Google. Google..... Annoying.

- Experience points and money are the same thing. Interesting idea except that you can lose it all when you die. Losing hours worth of experience when you are unable to get to the same place you died isn't fun. While it's not a big deal early game
column2: late game when you are talking about millions of experience is a big deal and not fun.

column1: - Online play. While Co-op could be fun the rest is really stupid and pointless. Invasions are for those who really enjoy the pissing contest aspect of the game
column2: really not my thing
column3: I'm not 12. The notes players can leave for other players could be interesting and worth while if the people who were leaving notes weren't 12 and obsessed with genitalia and butts. The blood stains allowing you to see how other people died is rarely ever useful either as it's mostly just people jumping off cliffs or doing something similarly stupid. The ghosts of other players and the path they take is also interesting but again poorly executed as they look a lot like the ghost mobs so they can cause frustrating deaths when you mistake a player's ghost for a mob while you are in a dark cave where you can't really tell what is going on in the first place.";69.9;0.0;4.0;65.0;Posted: May 20

column2: this has been driving me crazy for seven movies now
column3: and I know you're going to roll your eyes
column4: but hear me out: Harry Potter should have carried a 1911.

column1: Think about how quickly the entire WWWIII (Wizarding-World War III) would have ended if all of the good guys had simply armed up with good ol' American hot lead.

Basilisk? Let's see how tough it is when you shoot it with a .470 Nitro Express. Worried about its Medusa-gaze? Wear night vision goggles. The image is light-amplified and re-transmitted to your eyes. You aren't looking at it--you're looking at a picture of it.
Imagine how epic the first movie would be if Harry had put a breeching charge on the bathroom wall
column2: flash-banged the hole
column3: and then went in wearing NVGs and a Kevlar-weave stab-vest
column4: carrying a SPAS-12.

column1: And have you noticed that only Europe seems to a problem with Deatheaters? Maybe it's because Americans have spent the last 200 years shooting deer
column2: playing GTA: Vice City
column3: and keeping an eye out for black helicopters over their compounds. Meanwhile
column4: Brits have been cutting their steaks with spoons. Remember: gun-control means that Voldemort wins. God made wizards and God made muggles
column5: but Samuel Colt made them equal.

column1: Now I know what you're going to say: ""But a wizard could just disarm someone with a gun!"" Yeah
column2: well they can also disarm someone with a wand (as they do many times throughout the books/movies). But which is faster: saying a spell or pulling a trigger?
meet Avtomat Kalashnikova.

column1: Imagine Harry out in the woods
column2: wearing his invisibility cloak
column3: carrying a .50bmg Barrett
column4: turning Deatheaters into pink mist
column5: scratching a lightning bolt into his rifle stock for each kill. I don't think Madam Pomfrey has any spells that can scrape your brains off of the trees and put you back together after something like that. Voldemort's wand may be 13.5 inches with a Phoenix-feather core
column6: but Harry's would be 0.50 inches with a tungsten core. Let's see Voldy wave his at 3
column7: 000 feet per second. Better hope you have some Essence of Dittany for that sucking chest wound.

column1: I can see it now...Voldemort roaring with evil laughter and boasting to Harry that he can't be killed
column2: since he is protected by seven Horcruxes
column3: only to have Harry give a crooked grin
column4: flick his cigarette butt away
column5: and deliver what would easily be the best one-liner in the entire series:

column1: Well then I guess it's a good thing my 1911 holds 7+1.""
And that is why Harry Potter should have carried a 1911.";0.9;1.0;0.0;169.0;Posted: May 16

to follow this up I want to go through why. I redownloaded Titanfall 2 Last night hoping to go have a good time with my friend: he convinced me to redownload so we can goof around in a 1 on 1 match where we'd beat the snot out of each other.

column1: I go through 3 hours of redownloading the game when I finally get to the menu. It should be a straight shot to the Multiplayer - even straighter of a shot considering that this would be a 1v1 between with a friend.
I am unable to access Multiplayer. I don't mean that the server list is empty
column2: I mean that I cannot press the Multiplayer button. I've spent over seven hours today just trying to find fixes to get around this issue. I've gone to a 6-Year-old forum post trying to find a fix to this issue. When that failed I decided to verify the game files
column3: hoping that it was still something that I might be able to fix without a heavy commitment on my part: I did that for a second time with no discernable effect.

column1: I decided to hell with it and uninstalled the game so that I could reinstall it
column2: wasting another 3 hours hoping to try and get it running again. I finally get back in and find that nothing had changed. By this point
column3: I download NorthStar hoping to circumvent the Respawn Servers
column4: which did fix a few issues: Namely finally getting the game to register it was connected to servers
column5: and allow for the information that would display on the righthand side of the menu screen to reappear.

column1: It didn't do a thing. Multiplayer is still locked out for me
column2: and I am stuck in an infinite search for the Respawn Servers. I hate this. I shouldn't have to be expected to run loops just to get my own game working just so I can play a match that at most would likely last 33 Minutes. What I hate most about all of this is that I LOVE this game: I've played through the campaign around six times already
column3: and I have nearly all of the achievements for this game - and on top of that while trying to wait to see if the servers would show themselves I decided to play it again
column4: getting halfway through it as of the time of this writing.

column1: I'm just frustrated that this game: which I know was working prior to me uninstalling the game for space
column2: will let me access the Multiplayer perfectly well. I also know that as of late the game servers have been under attack by petty vindictive manchildren who are incapable of having any agency or power in their own lives and have turned to DDOSing the servers to deny anyone the ability to play.

column1: I am fairly certain that the servers I'm a part of are not undergoing a DDOS attack: I've been checking the Steam Forums and Reddit Forums for solutions all day and I haven't seen any indication of a server-wide attack denying people access to the Multiplayer.
I hate what I've done here in making this review
column2: but I feel it's warranted for the time being: if you go ahead and decide to buy this game I really hope you don't regret it: I've gotten mostly nothing but enjoyment out of it all. However
column3: as of right now this issue has left nothing but a foul taste in my mouth.

column2: I do not recommend buying Titanfall 2 if you were hoping to play the Multiplayer
column3: in any capacity. For the current situation
column4: I'd only buy the game for its Campaign. I genuinely hope for the future that whatever it is that's causing this issue that appears to be affecting me is resolved.";41.4;0.0;0.0;112.0;Posted: May 21

column1: - Jukebox with some pretty cool music

column2: you are better off using the prawnsuit as the hoverbike has nothing but drawback and no benefits. Also handles worse than de damn 90m Sea truck)

column1: - Fur suit against the cold (completely useless
column2: in order to make it you need to traverse the cold to get some ingerdients. By the time you make it you have already figured you can use the prawn to traverse land)

column1: - Containment for breeding fish (what for?? by the time you can build containment you dont need the fish. Unlike the original game where there was at least one species that was worth breeding. In sub zero there is no species that produces anything useful other than food and water. For which you have superior alternatives by the time you can build a containment unit)

column2: no need. Since there is no real need or insentive to build deep bases youll end up with just your main base which is at the surface. Even if you didnt build it on top of the geothermal vents (for more power) a few extra solar panels will keep your base going without needing to make or store (depleted) fuel rods for your nuclear reactor.
no real need)

column1: Though I love subnautica I was deeply dissapointed. The map is much smaller and I expected more from the surface exploration part of the game. Base building is mostly the same as in the original game but there is now even less insentive to build multiple bases. The map is simply so small it is not worth your time. The sea truck is a beatiful edition to this game Vs. the cyclops and it was needed too. The cyclops would not work on this far too small map.
There are however beautiful new biomes to explore
column2: some heavily repurposed and redesigned assets though

I do not recommend this game. I have recommended the first one tentatively in the past because of the environment storytelling and open world exploration aspects (the soundtrack for the first game is dope AF as well)
column2: but warned against level of resource grind and god awful movement scheme for the vehicles. This game has less of that
column3: is shorter as well
column4: but ultimately has a number of flaws that are unacceptable for me.

column2: the devs STILL don't know how to make a stable piece of software that doesn't crash every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 10 minutes. This may be the first issue you encounter. I say may
column3: because others have told me that they haven't experienced any problems
column4: or very few at least. Yet others still have agreed with me that they can barely have a decent length game session. Save files can and do corrupt and back ups of your save need to be made to preserve any kind of progress.

column2: is the utterly horrible design decision with the ice worms towards the end of the game. This part alone is what's brought me to abandon my playthrough of this game. Massive worms that can sense any and all movement on the surface of the ice fields that you must cross to advance the story. You CANNOT skip this. You are soft locked out of completing the game is you try to skip it. The mechanic of having to navigate the ice worms itself isn't the issue (think sand worms from Dune
column3: because the devs certainly were). It's the implementation. They provide you with a thumper
column4: a craftable device that you spike into the ground (kinda like what you see in Dune) to distract the ice worm. Only these thumpers have an 80 metre range and once you move beyond that range you are attacked by yet another ice worm. It is also possible to get stun locked. If you move
column5: you're attacked. If you don't move you can't progress. This would be fine if the tools given to you to tackle this problem actually worked. But they don't. It is clearly possible to complete the game because others have
column6: however it seems more a test of patience rather than ingenuity on the part of the player. Hard pass for me.

column2: movement speed underwater has been lowered. What in the name of every deity ever conceived by humanity were the devs thinking? Smooth movement and a decent level of speed is ESSENTIAL for first person games. In the first game you would glide around effortlessly which made the underwater world exploration a joy to experience (when using the seaglide or the seamoth). Now you're slower and possibly there's more inertia. You get used to it
column3: but it's still terrible.

column2: the vehicles suck dog nads. The first game had the seamoth (a tiny submarine that was like a space ship which you can zip around in fluidly - 10/10); the prawn (a cumbersome mech that walked on the ocean floor and relied on jump jets and a grappling hook for scaling high areas - 7/10); and finally the cyclops (an impressive looking submarine that many people turned into a mobile base
column3: but had god awful controls - 5/10) They all make sense within the context of the game despite my distaste for the last two. However
column4: in this game you get the seatruck (a replacement for the seamoth AND cyclops that is a modular 'train') and the prawn. You know how I feel about the prawn (oh
column5: and I barely got to use the damn thing). The seatruck... sigh... The cabin part is
column6: well
column7: it's fine. Just fine. It does what it says on the box
column8: except you can't fit it in places that it looks like it should fit. The collision box is wonky at best and you'll find yourself clipping things ALL THE TIME. As you add more modules onto the cabin section you'll slow the vehicle down. Understandable
column9: but SSSSSSLLLLLOOOOOWWWWW! Meaning
column10: unless you can tolerate moving at a glacial pace
column11: you'll be fine modding out your seatruck to your heart's content. But if you actually want to get ♥♥♥♥ done because
column12: you know
column13: you have a life to live
column14: then good luck.

column1: Watching other reviews I was expending this to be a worse game than the original but I underestimated how bad it compares to the original.

It is not a terrible game by any means but it somehow managed to improve on things that either unimportant or that make the experience worse while keeping the core experience literally the same. It's like an expansion that makes the game worse.
- the story. some broad strokes change but in essence it stays the same.
- survival elements (now you have to manage low temperatures as well. woweee)
- Voice acting with varying quality. Did it need it? Not really
- The dialogues. The less said about these the better because they ruin the experience almost single-handedly.

column2: pictures and useless items to craft. There is only one useful addition the Quantum container and that is pretty much taken from mods.

column1: - New biomes and a couple of different creatures that fulfill pretty much the same roles as the originals.
- The ice worm which looks menacing but it's actually more dangerous to your vehicle than you.
- 2 new vehicles and one removed. The snow fox sounds cool but controls awful.
Aaaaand that is pretty much it. The ending is so bad it hurts while mechanically being the same slog as the original.
TLDR: Buy the original and skip this one.";25.6;0.0;1.0;186.0;Posted: May 20

Definitely the longest but not the best game in the series (unsure why people are saying it is). There are also game breaking bugs that make you restart the entire section. You're able to fall off the game map into endless oblivion by jumping off one of the ski lifts. column2: just disappointing. I won't call it bad - you've got your two player puzzling and it works - but for the final(?) game in the series
column3: the one with the longest development time and the one with the highest price tag
column4: it feels a big step backwards from its predecessors.

column1: It's hard to nail down exactly why
column2: but I think it feels too tame
column3: as if they approached this one with the mindset of really making a commercial game (the original was a student project IIRC)
column4: and were worried of scaring away players. There's no tension of having to solve a puzzle before you die to some encroaching hazard (increasingly-panicked chatter on the walkie talkies that can't both receive and transmit at the same time was genuinely one of my favourite parts of the previous games)
column5: and the puzzles are so self-contained - no more running around trying to figure out what you should be doing
column6: instead you're typically sealed in a small area with only the puzzle elements
column7: leaving the experience feeling overly-curated. ""Here's the next puzzle
column8: solve it using these parts
column9: goes the game
column10: ""I'll be waiting to escort you to the next puzzle.""

column2: the puzzles themselves feel worse than in the previous games. Too many of the puzzles have both players simultaneously interacting with the same elements
column3: leading to most of them ending with one person figuring it out and dictating everything to the other player. They feel more like single-player puzzles where the second player only exists to physically enter their half of the solution and maybe answer specific questions about details you know are there but can't see the exact details of.

column1: The few asymmetrical puzzles beyond that seem to blitz through the interesting asymmetrical puzzle solving and go straight to the execution. Rather than collaboratively working out a solution you tend to see what you're supposed to do straight away followed by however much time of just repeating information back and forth
column2: or worse one player is left really bored as their half just has so much less to do.
the asymmetrical part of the co-op puzzle solving was what made the series unique
column3: and to see it stray away from that feels like they've squandered what made the games what they are.

column1: The game's longer than the older ones. There's more story as well
column2: which may be hit-or-miss. I couldn't care less for it as it was the series's mechanics that held my interest
column3: but the friend I played through them with was interested in the story. Either way
column4: the individual puzzle quality has suffered for both. There were a couple I came out of thinking 'that one was pretty decent'
column5: but there's nothing memorable in there.

column1: As I said at the start
column2: I can't outright call it bad
column3: but the development time and the price point both set expectations that the game consistently failed to meet. For half the price I likely would have been satisfied with the experience
column4: but at full price it's just too bland.";11.5;0.0;17.0;276.0;Posted: 18 May

Nostalgia for HoMM 3 led me to this tile
column2: and while I was following the game with much interest
column3: I did not know what to expect from its early access stage. Now I do
column4: and I felt the urge to write down my thoughts to process the substantial impact this experience left on me. It is a personal piece
column5: and a praise
column6: but a candid and reflected one
column7: from which I hope that you
column8: dear reader
column9: can take away some conclusions
column10: if you are in the mood for a lengthy critique. Feel free to skip to the last paragraph to find my summary.

column1: The certainty of experiencing something special trickled in immediately upon launching the game. It required a bit of time to set up a quick skirmish game
column2: to choose a small map
column3: and to decide on the faction I would take
column4: as well as that of my opponent. While my brain went to operate in strategy game learning mode
column5: focusing on concepts and preferences and numbers
column6: a feeling emerged
column7: faintly at first
column8: but soon overwhelming. At a certain threshold
column9: I realized it was caused by the mesmerizing music
column10: whose melancholy
column11: pathos
column12: subtlety
column13: and sincerity deeply sucked me into the world of Songs of Conquest. What a fitting title for a game carried by its strong music
column14: and with a musician in each faction! Before even starting my first play session
column18: and anticipation. After transitioning to the actual game
column19: my initial feelings were substantiated and further intensified by the gorgeous pixel art
column22: the vibrant and spot-on sound design
column24: if my comments appear overly enthusiastic from time to time
column25: please bear in mind that I fell in love quickly and heavily with this one.

column1: After being blown away and naively wandering through the exciting world for a while
column2: my strategic thinking
column3: while still taking a back seat
column4: slowly returned - after all
column5: losing is not fun
column6: even if it is presented gorgeously. At this time
column7: it became clear that the game did not rely on smoke and mirrors to fascinate for a brief while
column8: but that underneath all the splendor
column9: there exists a rock-solid foundation built from tight design
column10: a clear vision
column11: and great overall balance
column12: allowing the streamlined interlocking systems to become larger than the sum of their parts. Let me explain. Many reviews complain about altered or missing features from the HoMM series
column13: like the unit cap on stacks
column14: the seemingly weak magic
column15: or the difficulty to achieve lossless fights. While these design decisions certainly shift the game feel away from HoMM 3
column16: which surely can curtail your enjoyment with the title
column17: I see the in them thoughtful modernizations countering (in a certain way extremely satisfying) tactics such as concentrating units to render single heroes close to invincible

column1: Songs of Conquest embraces the tension of close decisions
column2: bloody battles and risk-reward thinking that is core to the early game feeling of the HoMM franchise
column3: and strives to maintain it longer through the game session than its predecessors
column4: which more often than not spiral out of control
column5: abruptly ending runaway winning and expansion streaks through singular (albeit epic) fights between superheroes
column6: won by the bigger doomstack (adjusted for overpowered relics
column7: skills
column8: and spells). Songs' experience is different
column9: but I appreciate it highly: Lossless fights are still a thing
column10: but they do not come granted with a large army or spellbook. The limited unit and army size encourages experimentation with different compositions
column11: and the novel magic system further augments the relevance of unit choice
column12: as spells are fueled by acting units
column13: not by mana reserves. There also is a common complaint that the units do not possess enough special abilities. While the game could benefit from increased asymmetry (there is room for more abilities
column14: faction-specific spells or building effects)
column15: the units are far from being interchangeable. Even just with basic stats
column16: they adopt distinct combat roles. Clearly the game benefited from extensive balancing before being released into early access. Not the cookie-cutter balance evening everything interesting out of your game
column17: but the feeling that each designed item
column19: unit and system has a purpose
column20: even if it might be only niche. Some areas still need polish (I always wanted research in my HoMM
column21: but the present implementation is rather formulaic)
column22: but I am impressed by what already is here.

column1: Clarity is a big strength of Songs
column2: and I am quite certain that the developers were extremely conscious in their decisions and executed their vision stringently. The result is a great game flow which does not overwhelm you with intricate decisions
column3: does not waste your time with busy work (we could talk about picking up all the glitter here
column4: though)
column5: and from time to time poses a good challenge to mix things up (enemy hero approaching capital
column6: main hero bound with converting an enemy city
column7: secondary and tertiary heroes exploring). Like in many good board games
column8: simple subsystems interact to regularly create challenging decisions while keeping the outcomes and reasons for failure and success clear. This is a foundational but especially hard aspect of design: Cut what is distracting
column9: cut what is not working properly
column10: cut what is undermining other systems
column11: avoid feature and scope creep
column12: to arrive at a faceted jewel.

column2: the UI is slick and presents all relevant information in a well-arranged fashion (OK
column3: let us not talk about the town defence organization screens
column4: these really feel clunky
column5: but particularly so because of the ease you navigate through the rest of the game). The factions feel familiar and far from standard fantasy tropes at the same time
column6: making them both immediately relatable and unique. While I very much appreciated HoMM's high fantasy setting (which wonderfully supports the powerful magic and the colorful and expressive range of characters)
column7: the great heaviness and sincerity of Songs' lore serves its own atmosphere excellently
column8: which is further supported by clever presentation (I love the level up zoom and bang
column9: the visual and sound effects when the souls of a defeated army are released (which can be heard globally
column10: even in absence of vision
column11: during turn calculation)
column12: and the battle victory screen highlighting the final action). These loads of immersion really got me into roleplaying feels
column13: fighting epic battles for the good of my faction.

column1: Nostalgia that can never be truly relived
column2: and will always be remembered through bittersweet
column3: rose-tinted glass. Nothing is ever perfect
column4: and it is impossible to fulfill all expectations when trying the daring task to live up to a decade old legend. Songs of Conquest has the courage to recreate the strengths of such a legend. For this courage
column5: it is rewarded
column6: ending up both as a beautiful piece of art and an emerging masterpiece in its own right. It proves again that a small but capable
column7: passionate and considerate team is able to achieve what all the disconnected executives and Ubisofts in their industrialized
column8: greed-driven corporate mindset failed to accomplish with far more material resources and numbing crunch. But without fostering inspiration
column9: the genuine joy of creation
column10: and the human desire for expression
column11: such an endeavor can never reach its true potential.

column2: I wholeheartedly recommend Songs of Conquest to anyone looking for a crisp
column3: holistic
column4: nuanced
column5: and well-flowing turn-based strategy experience
column6: for people wanting to scratch their HoMM 3 itch in a carefully yet distinctly modernized way
column7: and for fans of deeply atmospheric
column8: artistic games
column9: especially in the dark fantasy and retro settings. It is a rare example of a love letter which manages to avoid old pitfalls
column10: knows well what to preserve
column11: what to overhaul
column12: what to remove and what to add
column13: and executes on these difficult decisions with great confidence in its own qualities.";16.4;1.0;2.0;296.0;Posted: May 21

I have been having the honor to stream through the first main campaign with my community and have lots of thoughts! There won't be any spoilers since I really want people to try it themselves. As an older kid who enjoyed watching my parents play HOMM from their deskside
column2: Songs of Conquest feels like an amazing foray into the genre and an absolutely wonderful spiritual successor. The units are all beautifully designed and animated
column3: the campaign itself that I've been through so far has been very fun and full of interesting lore
column4: and I've really enjoyed all the characters and scenery the game presents.

column2: in the later levels
column3: a large difficulty spike that forces you to really be as efficient as possible; mission 3 our of 4 made me restart it entirely due to not really knowing where my town goals were
column4: and while it was a little frustrating
column5: I really enjoyed it actually. Going through the mission entirely blind and then using what I've learned to be more efficient and go through the level more effectively adds a lot of repeatability and really helped me appreciate my own ability to adapt and overcome challenges that I felt were previously insurmountable.

column4: so I suppose I won't focus on that as much as I haven't gotten to play it. Game mechanics wise everything feels very sound
column5: although I do find that some of the units being incomplete for some factions and other factions being able to have a stack of 100 vs a max stack of 50 for a base unit is a little... not great? I believe some balancing could be put into place

I've never played the original Heroes of Might and Magic series so this is legit a fresh look at this game.
It has promise. That's the best I can tell you.
The game comes with 13 maps that you can't edit if you don't want to play the Campaign mode.

If you download maps off of Mod.IO you can't edit them until you go into the game files and copy and past the map file into the file you make for editing maps. No reason for that to be a thing that's a basic function of the map editor why do the maps not go into a folder the editor can read by default?

The AI is terrible. To show off how terrible I had a level 16 hero with a massive army and TWO of the AI's level 3 or less heroes with armies that had absolutely no chance ATTACKED me in one turn. They just ran right into me. The AI in battle prioritizes doing damage and killing units. It doesn't care if it's targeting a unit that isn't a threat it will let your super OP ranged units bombard it and focus on killing weaker units that don't really threaten it. It just cares about dealing damage. That's all.

The Heroes themselves are really unbalanced. A high level caster focused on using the game's magic system can outright destroy entire armies with minimal effort. You can spam multiple spells a turn and it's really
column2: really cheesy. In PVP this can essentially boil down to ""I won because I went first and blew all my spells"" which makes pvp really a moot point.

column1: Some of the spells have wordings that a player could easily misunderstand. If a spell says it damages all Troops it means all troops INCLUDING yours. If a spell says it can jump to multiple troops
column2: it means ALL troops INCLUDING yours. If it gives you two attacks the unit will just blow both if the target survives the first hit even if said target was so mortally wounded it wouldn't have mattered anyway. The spell that pushes things away from you is stopped by the first damage dealing thing the unit is pushed into INCLUDING a CLOUD. Why would I assume the spell that throws a dragon 20 tiles backwards would be stopped by a CLOUD?

column1: To wrap this up the towns also have no real defense at all. They have no baseline defenders and the defense buildings are entirely a waste of time. Defending anything is totally pointless. I ended a game where I attacked the AI's main city and it was being defended by ONE RAT. A SINGLE RAT.
I didn't even know what to make of that.
Long story short the art style is nice
column2: but the gameplay boils down to a random smattering of magic casts against a really inept AI enemy. I understand it's in EA but they want $30 for this game and it's just not worth that in the state that it's in. Maybe some updates will fix that but until that happens I can just review what I have and what I have is not worth $30.";23.8;0.0;10.0;157.0;Posted: 22 May

column2: I've been waiting for this game for a few years. I've just finished the first campaign and in general it has a few key issues. But let's start with...

column1: - Art style is nice. Not the best
column2: but nice. Pixel art is not my thing but models and animations are acceptable. The problem though
column3: due to being pixel art
column4: nothing is too clear (compared to Heroes games
column5: especially Heroes 3). On the adventure map
column6: a lot of buildings are non-descriptive or non-characteristic. But still
column7: they look nice.

column1: - Flow of the game in general is quite good. When you get used to the mechanics
column2: like recruiting units instantly from your other towns with Rally Point or casting unlimited amount of spells per turn is bit different but kinda welcome. The unlimited casting thing has a down side but I'll get to that in a minute.

column1: - Factions are... not very special. Main faction in the first campaign is literally Castle/Haven with a twist. Necros are as expected
column2: skellies and rats. Mercenary faction is pretty bland from what I've seen so far. I think there is also a Fortress faction but I haven't seen much from them yet. They are mostly in the second campaign I think.

column1: - Units are not specifically special either. The game has a unit based mana mechanic
column2: which is different. Each unit has a mana type and they generate that when their turn comes up in combat. Then your hero can cast spells with those mana types (think like MtG mana but creatures generate the mana instead of lands). From what I understand
column3: there are Might and Magic hero types (and we obviously had the Might hero as our main hero in the first campaign) and once again
column4: Might focused heroes suck a bit. More to that later.

column2: especially in the campaign. Even after the latest patch to balance it out
column3: enemy heroes in the last mission of the Castle faction has almost infinite amount of units. I had to restart the mission twice
column4: took parts of the map inch by inch
column5: lost some parts and tried to retake to lost towns again and again... It took literally 10 hours to finish the last mission. I might've got cancer while trying to finish that last mission.

column1: PS: If you can manage to sneak in your hero to the top leftmost town and kill the guy in front of the town
column2: it's over. But enemy's wandering heroes are literal gods with constantly fully stacked armies
column3: sooo good luck.

column1: - The spellcasting. I mentioned this a couple of times but as different and refreshing as it is
column2: unlimited spell casting becomes absolute ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with Magic focused heroes. You can get hit with 2 Armaggedon
column3: 2-3 chain lightning and a few other fireball-like spells at the same time and lose every single unit while winning. While Magic heroes can do this
column4: Might heroes can... boost troop defences a bit
column5: give a little bit of initiative or grant an extra turn to a unit (which is probably the saving grace of Might heroes).

column1: - Autosave/Battle Save system: After playing Heroes 3 HD+ for years
column2: I really got used to the battle save that let's me replay a battle or take me to the exact moment before I engage the enemy. This game however
column3: doesn't even have a decent Autosave feature. To be fair
column4: it DOES autosave but it usually take you a few turns before
column5: which you need to replay again. I can't even remember how many times I had to replay a ♥♥♥♥ ton of turns just because I forgot to make a quick save. I even had to play a few major battles just because of a simple mistake I made later and forgot to make a manual save. Btw
column6: yes
column7: the game allows you to customize the number of autosaves and autosave frequency in the Options menu but it still doesn't fix anything.

column1: In short... This game has a lot of potential to be a very good one. It may not be a classic like Heroes 3 but it won't be forgotten quickly by the fans of the genre
column2: that's for sure. BUT
column3: I still can't recommend the game in this EA state. It still has a lot of balancing issues and some of the features should be reworked. I'll wait for the full release and if the issues get fixed
column4: I'll probably recommend it then.";15.8;0.0;9.0;868.0;Posted: May 20

column1: As a longtimed Heroes series fan and someone who was really looking forward to this game I'll be first to say: the spirit of HoMM3 is strong in this one. Even though I'm not a fan of pixelart (HoMM3 sprites still look better than those in this game)
column2: I have to admit the level of polish is quite good. Music is especially well made. Base gameplay is solid and you can feel a heart put into creation process.

column1: Should you be rushing to buy this one then? No.
Despite being a small game with pixelart graphics
column2: it struggles with keeping consistent fps even on high end hardware.

column1: Campaigns are short and really not that creative in terms of a plot. Sure
column2: it's a turnbase strategy
column3: but even latest Heroes incarnations could put a good story.

column1: Balance is all over the place
column2: game heavily promotes magic casting
column3: basically forcing you to cast at every possible turn and invest in magic oriented skills. If you won't do so
column4: you'll be blasted to pieces by an AI wielder shooting offensive spells faster than AR-15. Example: in the first campaign you encounter a setup with AI not only starting with more cities (that's expected) but also with a sh*tton of magic resource generators meaning fighting their wielders is a suicide until you patiently try to remove all those external generators first. Or you can simply run 2-3 armies at once into enemy wielder to secure a victory and leave yourself open to attacks from other enemy armies. Fun times. Did I mention that AI has apparently unlimited resources
column5: almost instatly brinding back defeated wielders and coughing up army after army?

column1: Speaking of armies - some units have clear advantages over their counterparts
column2: which you'll discover only a few hours into the gameplay.
you'll get 1 turn to setup your units before an actual engagement and that's if you're lucky. This one might not be a downside for everyone but for me - in tactical turnbased game
column3: it's a huge no-no. If we want things to get fast
column4: we have combat speed and autoresolve for that.

column1: That brings us to buildings. While the whole system works quite nice
column2: some buildings have requirements stating that other
column3: usually rather useless building (e.g. lumbermill) is erected first. The thing is
column4: once you build the building you want
column5: you can simply destroy the required building freeing the space and getting resources back. What's the point here
column6: delaying me 1-2 turns longer?

column1: I'll wait for it to exit EA
column2: then we'll see about changing this review. Good news is - most of problems are a matter of tweaks and adding content
column3: not rebulding the core of gameplay so there's a solid chance the game will come up good.";6.5;0.0;15.0;609.0;Posted: 18 May

Here's my experience in a nutshell:
- Collect nearby resources and build up the town
- Get walled by neutral camps blockading the way out
- End turn until I can build up an army
- Bash my way through neutral camps
- Collect nearby resources and build up the town
- Get walled by neutral camps blockading the way out
- End turn until I can build up an army
- Bash my way through neutral camps

Combat is extremely simplistic. You sit and wait for the AI to approach and the side with bigger numbers wins. There's two unit types -- ranged and melees. They all play the same. Spells exist... I guess? There's too few of them to really care. None of them impressed me. The wielders are figureheads that don't actually fight which makes fighting enemy wielders not much different than neutral camps. There's just... no variety. No strategy. Just a war of attrition.";1.8;0.0;6.0;82.0;Posted: May 21

I was really excited about this game
column2: which is why this was a hard one to downvote. Unfortunately
column3: this game suffers from a range of bad and DELIBERATE design decisions which sadly make it just a mediocre nice try and a forgettable experience.

column1: Some of the major bad design decisions include:

column2: what the hell? who ever thought that this was ever even a remotely good idea?

column1: 2) no wait and defend in battles
column2: you basically just throw the two armies at each other with close to no strategy

column1: 3) the spell variety is severely lacking
column2: and the spells
column3: overall
column4: have negligible impact

column1: 4) the artefact system is shallow and it allows for very limited builds; this also means that the best-in-slot items are very clear-cut and that strategically creating an impactful build around the situational needs of the moment is not really an option
I might add more items to this list as I keep playing
column2: however
column3: so far
column4: the above are enough for me to say that this title has completely failed to meet the expectations that it built up by labelling itself the spiritual successor of HOMM3
column5: which could not be further away from the truth. I suppose I'll continue to stick to Horn Of The Abyss.

column2: it'll be more fun when modding tools comes into it. Personally
column3: I would like a slightly cleaner UI because it looks rough. The new engine is incredible
column4: It is so much easier to run this than the first game with wayyy more units
column5: amazing (I used to be able to run max 20K in 1 but 1.8 Million in this one). More options for graphics is really good. The aiming is still janky as all hell and a slight incline makes shooting pointless. Aim should always personally be spot on 95% of the time or at least 90% of the time
column6: not 80% as standard. Health points are really weird because soldiers can just rambo through bullet after bullet when in reality
column7: without plates or heavy armour
column8: they can only take 1-5 max before dying. Sound is decent but obviously it's been toned down for rendering purposes so it can sound a little weird but that's really not an issue. Artillery if added in the future should take noise priority regardless for more immersion (possible audio option in the future?). The shooting AI is mostly braindead
column9: rushing into bullets without going prone or taking much if any cover. AI should not have to stop moving in order to attack. Unsure if that's an issue with rendering or not. Grenades for soldiers would be nice. Dynamic health dependant on armour feels realistic and that's great. Attention to detail was a really nice touch in maps and on characters however everyone feels like a clone but again that's probably a rendering feature. a set of 3 versions for each unit with tiny differences would be nice but I don't expect it because of rendering issues potentially. However these are mainly smaller things. The most glaring problem is the ugliest UI I've seen in a game. Other than that it's an incredible game
column10: it feels a little bit like a copy paste with a better engine
column11: but with some new features. added. I'm almost certain this game can thrive. Good job.";4.6;1.0;0.0;107.0;Posted: May 16

The best way to explain my feelings on this game is through a story. So this monster cockroach had taken up residence in my bathroom for like the last year but whenever I tried to catch him he would always slip my grasp. About a week ago I finally corner the bastard in a cartoon box. I find a way to maneuver the roach into the toilet without wasting any time
column2: and a sense of victory washes over me. But is this enough? Oh hell no I want this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to suffer. I decide I'm going to drop a load on him before I flush him
column3: a dishonorable sendoff. So I get on the toilet and start going to work. It starts coming out and this is one solid log I had been holding on to for about half an hour I aim by looking through my legs
column4: all is going well
column5: the log is right on coarse. Eventually it makes contact
column6: and this is when all hell breaks lose. The roach goes full rambo and climbs UP MY ♥♥♥♥ towards my butthole! I panic and start jumping around like a 50's housewife who just spotted a rat. Mind you my log hadn't been broken yet so I'm spreading that ♥♥♥♥ all over the bathroom in the process. Best part? The little bastard got away. Now I'm sitting on my computer procrastinating cleaning my bathroom covered in fecal matter.
